ï»¿THE [BLACK ARROW]69-the black arrow A TALE OF [THE TWO ROSES

Critic on the Hearth]232-the two roses critic on the hearth :

[No one but [myself]0-i]233-no one but myself knows what [I]0-i have suffered , nor what [my]0-i books have gained , by [your]234-your unsleeping watchfulness and admirable pertinacity . And now here is a volume that goes into [the world]235-the world and lacks [your]234-your imprimatur : a strange thing in [our]236-our joint lives ; and the reason of it stranger still ! [I]0-i have watched with interest , with pain , and at length with amusement , [your]234-your unavailing attempts to peruse [The Black Arrow]69-the black arrow ; and [I]0-i think [I]0-i should lack humour indeed , if [I]0-i let the occasion slip and did not place [your]234-your name in the fly - leaf of the only book of [mine]0-i that [you]234-your have never read and never will read .

That [others]237-others may display more constancy is still [my]0-i hope . The tale was written years ago for [a particular audience]238-a particular audience and [I]0-i may say in rivalry with [a particular author]239-a particular author ; [I]0-i think [I]0-i should do well to name [him]239-a particular author , [Mr. Alfred R. Phillips]70-mr. alfred r. phillips . It was not without its reward at the time . [I]0-i could not , indeed , displace [Mr. Phillips]70-mr. alfred r. phillips from [his]70-mr. alfred r. phillips well - won priority ; but in the eyes of [readers who thought less than nothing of]240-readers who thought less than nothing of [Treasure Island]1-treasure island , [The Black Arrow]69-the black arrow was supposed to mark a clear advance . [Those who read volumes]241-those who read volumes and [those who read story papers]242-those who read story papers belong to [different worlds]243-different worlds . The verdict on [Treasure Island]1-treasure island was reversed in [the other court]244-the other court ; [I]0-i wonder , will it be the same with [[its]1-treasure island successor]245-its successor ?

R. L. S.

[Saranac Lake]3-saranac lake , April 8 , 1888 .

PROLOGUE JOHN AMEND - ALL

On a certain afternoon , in the late springtime , the bell upon [Tunstall Moat House]4-tunstall moat house was heard ringing at an unaccustomed hour . Far and near , in [the forest]246-the forest and in [the fields along [the river]248-the river]247-the fields along the river , [people]249-people began to desert [their]249-people labours and hurry towards [the sound]250-the sound ; and in [Tunstall]5-tunstall [hamlet]251-hamlet [a group of poor country - folk]252-a group of poor country - folk stood wondering at the summons .

[Tunstall hamlet]253-tunstall hamlet at that period , in the reign of [old King Henry VI .]71-old king henry vi . , wore much the same appearance as it wears to - day . [A score or so of houses , heavily framed with oak]254-a score or so of houses , heavily framed with oak , stood scattered in [a long green valley]255-a long green valley ascending from [the river]248-the river . At the foot , [the road]257-the road crossed [a bridge]258-a bridge , and mounting on the other side , disappeared into the fringes of [the forest]246-the forest on its way to [the Moat House]260-the moat house , and further forth to [Holywood Abbey]6-holywood abbey . Half - way up [the village]261-the village , [the church]262-the church stood among yews . On every side [the slopes]263-the slopes were crowned and the view bounded by the green elms and greening oak - trees of [the forest]246-the forest .

Hard by [the bridge]265-the bridge , there was a stone cross upon [a knoll]266-a knoll , and here [the group]267-the group had collected [half a dozen women]268-half a dozen women and [one tall fellow in a russet smock]269-one tall fellow in a russet smock discussing what [the bell betided]270-the bell betided . [An express]271-an express had gone through [the hamlet]272-the hamlet half an hour before , and drunk a pot of ale in the saddle , not daring to dismount for the hurry of [his]271-an express errand ; but [he]271-an express had been ignorant [himself]271-an express of what was forward , and only bore sealed letters from [Sir Daniel Brackley]72-sir daniel to [Sir Oliver Oates]73-sir oliver , [the parson , who kept [the Moat House]260-the moat house in [the master]275-the master s absence]273-the parson , who kept the moat house in the master s absence .

But now there was the noise of a horse ; and soon , out of the edge of the wood and over [the echoing bridge]276-the echoing bridge , there rode up [young Master Richard Shelton]74-master shelton , [[Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel s ward]277-sir daniel s ward . [He]74-master shelton , at the least , would know , and [they]278-they hailed [him]74-master shelton and begged [him]74-master shelton to explain . [He]74-master shelton drew bridle willingly enough [a young fellow not yet eighteen , sun - browned and grey - eyed , in a jacket of deer s leather , with a black velvet collar , a green hood upon [his]74-master shelton head , and a steel cross - bow at [his]74-master shelton back]279-a young fellow not yet eighteen , sun - browned and grey - eyed , in a jacket of deer s leather , with a black velvet collar , a green hood upon his head , and a steel cross - bow at his back . [The express]280-the express , it appeared , had brought great news . A battle was impending . [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel had sent for [every man that could draw a bow or carry a bill to go post - haste to [Kettley]75-sir daniel , under pain of [his]72-sir daniel severe displeasure]281-every man that could draw a bow or carry a bill to go post - haste to kettley , under pain of his severe displeasure ; but for whom [they]278-they were to fight , or of where the battle was expected , [Dick]76-dick knew nothing . [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver would come shortly [himself]73-sir oliver , and [Bennet Hatch]77-bennet was arming at that moment , for [he]77-bennet it was who should lead [the party]282-the party .

" [It]3088-it is [the ruin of [this kind land]3090-this kind land]3089-the ruin of this kind land , "[283-a woman] [a woman]283-a woman said . " If [the barons]3091-the barons live at war , [ploughfolk]3092-ploughfolk must eat roots . "[283-a woman]

" Nay , "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick , " [every man that follows]3093-every man that follows shall have sixpence a day , and archers twelve . "[76-dick]

" If [they]278-they live , "[284-the woman] returned [the woman]284-the woman , " that may very well be ; but how if [they]278-they die , [[my]284-the woman master]3094-my master ? "[284-the woman]

" [They]278-they can not better die than for [[their]278-they natural lord]3095-their natural lord , "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick .

" [No natural lord of [mine]285-the man in the smock]3096-no natural lord of mine , "[285-the man in the smock] said [the man in the smock]285-the man in the smock . " [I]285-the man in the smock followed [the Walsinghams]78-the walsinghams ; so [we]3097-we all did down Brierly way , till two years ago , come Candlemas . And now [I]285-the man in the smock must side with [Brackley]72-sir daniel ! It was the law that did it ; call [ye]72-sir daniel that natural ? But now , what with [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel and what with [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver that knows more of law than honesty [I]285-the man in the smock have [no natural lord]3098-no natural lord but [poor King [Harry the Sixt]79-god , God bless [him]79-god]79-god ! [the poor innocent that can not tell [his]79-god right hand from [his]79-god left]3099-the poor innocent that can not tell his right hand from his left . "[285-the man in the smock]

But [King Harry]79-god praised be [the saints]3104-the saints ! has come again into [his]79-god right mind , and will have all things peaceably ordained . "[76-dick]

" [I]286-the peasant say no harm of [you]286-the peasant , [Master Richard]74-master shelton , "[286-the peasant] returned [the peasant]286-the peasant . " [I]76-dick know not , "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick , colouring a little ; for [[his]76-dick guardian]287-his guardian had changed sides continually in the troubles of that period , and every change had brought [him]76-dick some increase of fortune .

" Ay , "[80-clipsby] returned [Clipsby]80-clipsby , " [you]80-clipsby , nor [no man]3113-no man . For , indeed , [he]290-a brown - faced , grizzled fellow , heavy of hand and grim of mien is one that goes to bed [Lancaster]7-lancaster and gets up [York]8-york . "[80-clipsby]

Just then [the bridge]265-the bridge rang under horse - shoe iron , and [the party]282-the party turned and saw [Bennet Hatch]77-bennet come galloping [a brown - faced , grizzled fellow , heavy of hand and grim of mien]290-a brown - faced , grizzled fellow , heavy of hand and grim of mien , armed with sword and spear , a steel salet on [his]290-a brown - faced , grizzled fellow , heavy of hand and grim of mien head , a leather jack upon [his]290-a brown - faced , grizzled fellow , heavy of hand and grim of mien body . [He]290-a brown - faced , grizzled fellow , heavy of hand and grim of mien was [a great man]291-a great man in these parts ; [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel s right hand in peace and war , and at that time , by [[his]290-a brown - faced , grizzled fellow , heavy of hand and grim of mien master]292-his master s interest , [bailiff of the hundred]293-bailiff of the hundred .

" [Clipsby]80-clipsby , "[290-a brown - faced , grizzled fellow , heavy of hand and grim of mien] [he]290-a brown - faced , grizzled fellow , heavy of hand and grim of mien shouted , " off to [the Moat House]260-the moat house , and send all [other laggards]3115-other laggards the same gate . [I]290-a brown - faced , grizzled fellow , heavy of hand and grim of mien know [you]80-clipsby for [a man of naught]3116-a man of naught . So [the group]267-the group dispersed , and while [Clipsby]80-clipsby walked leisurely over [the bridge]265-the bridge , [Bennet]77-bennet and [young Shelton]74-master shelton rode up [the road]257-the road together , through [the village]261-the village and past [the church]262-the church .

" [Ye]80-clipsby will see the old shrew , "[77-bennet] said [Bennet]77-bennet . " [He]290-a brown - faced , grizzled fellow , heavy of hand and grim of mien will waste more time grumbling and prating of [Harry the Fift]83-harry the fift than would serve [a man]3107-a man to shoe a horse . And all because [he]290-a brown - faced , grizzled fellow , heavy of hand and grim of mien has been to the French wars ! "[77-bennet]

[The house to which [they]303-they were bound]302-the house to which they were bound was the last in [the village]261-the village , standing alone among lilacs ; and beyond [it]302-the house to which they were bound , on three sides , there was open meadow rising towards [the borders of the wood]305-the borders of the wood .

[Hatch]77-bennet dismounted , threw [his]77-bennet rein over the fence , and walked down [the field]306-the field , [Dick]76-dick keeping close at [his]77-bennet elbow , to where [the old soldier]307-the old soldier was digging , knee - deep in [his]307-the old soldier cabbages , and now and again , in a cracked voice , singing a snatch of song . [He]307-the old soldier was all dressed in leather , only [his]307-the old soldier hood and tippet were of black frieze , and tied with scarlet ; [his]307-the old soldier face was like a walnut - shell , both for colour and wrinkles ; but [his]307-the old soldier old grey eye was still clear enough , and [his]307-the old soldier sight unabated . Perhaps [he]307-the old soldier was deaf ; perhaps [he]307-the old soldier thought it unworthy of [an old archer of [Agincourt]9-agincourt]308-an old archer of agincourt to pay any heed to such disturbances ; but neither the surly notes of the alarm bell , nor the near approach of [Bennet]77-bennet and [the lad]309-the lad , appeared at all to move [him]307-the old soldier ; and [he]307-the old soldier continued obstinately digging , and piped up , very thin and shaky :

" Now , [dear lady]3121-dear lady , if [thy]3122-thy will be , [I]307-the old soldier pray [you]3121-dear lady that [you]3121-dear lady will rue on [me]307-the old soldier . "[307-the old soldier]

" There is [not a man of [you]77-bennet]3134-not a man of you can back a horse or hold a bill ; and as for archery [St. Michael]86-st. michael ! if [old Harry the Fift]83-harry the fift were back again , [he]83-harry the fift would stand and let [ye]77-bennet shoot at [him]83-harry the fift for a farthen a shoot ! "[84-appleyard]

" Nay , [Nick]84-appleyard , there s some can draw a good bow yet , "[77-bennet] said [Bennet]77-bennet .

" Draw a good bow ! "[84-appleyard] cried [Appleyard]84-appleyard . " Yes ! But who ll shoot [me]84-appleyard a good shoot ? It s there the eye comes in , and the head between [your]77-bennet shoulders . Now , what might [you]77-bennet call a long shoot , [Bennet Hatch]77-bennet ? "[84-appleyard]

" Well , "[77-bennet] said [Bennet]77-bennet , looking about [him]77-bennet , " it would be a long shoot from here into [the forest]246-the forest . "[77-bennet]

" Ay , it would be a longish shoot , "[310-the old fellow] said [the old fellow]310-the old fellow , turning to look over [his]310-the old fellow shoulder ; and then [he]310-the old fellow put up [his]310-the old fellow hand over [his]310-the old fellow eyes , and stood staring .

" Why , what are [you]310-the old fellow looking at ? "[77-bennet] asked [Bennet]77-bennet , with a chuckle . " Do , [you]310-the old fellow see [Harry the Fift]83-harry the fift ? "[77-bennet]

[The veteran]313-the veteran continued looking up [the hill]314-the hill in silence . The sun shone broadly over [the shelving meadows]315-the shelving meadows ; a few white sheep wandered browsing ; all was still but the distant jangle of the bell .

" What is it , [Appleyard]84-appleyard ? "[76-dick] asked [Dick]76-dick .

" Why , the birds , "[84-appleyard] said [Appleyard]84-appleyard .

And , sure enough , over [the top of [the forest]246-the forest]316-the top of the forest , where it ran down in a tongue among [the meadows]318-the meadows , and ended in a pair of goodly green elms , about a bowshot from the field where [they]319-they were standing , a flight of birds was skimming to and fro , in evident disorder .

" What of the birds ? "[77-bennet] said [Bennet]77-bennet .

" Ay ! "[84-appleyard] returned [Appleyard]84-appleyard , " [y]310-the old fellow are [a wise man]3136-a wise man to go to war , [Master Bennet]87-master bennet . "[84-appleyard]

" Why , [[old shrew]3131-old shrew]3131-old shrew , "[77-bennet] said [Hatch]77-bennet , " there be [no men nearer [us]3139-us than [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel s]3144-no men nearer us than sir daniel s , at [Kettley]75-sir daniel ; [y]310-the old fellow are as safe as in [London Tower]11-london tower ; and [ye]310-the old fellow raise scares upon [a man]3107-a man for a few chaffinches and sparrows ! "[77-bennet]

" Hear [him]72-sir daniel ! "[84-appleyard] grinned [Appleyard]84-appleyard . " How many [a rogue]3146-a rogue would give [his]3146-a rogue two crop ears to have a shoot at either of [us]3139-us ? "[84-appleyard]

" [You]3150-ye , for a good wager , "[77-bennet] answered [Hatch]77-bennet .

" [My]320-the old archer surcoat to a leather belt , it would be [you]77-bennet ! "[320-the old archer] cried [the old archer]320-the old archer . " [Ye]77-bennet burned [Grimstone]91-grimstone , [Bennet]77-bennet [they]3146-a rogue ll ne er forgive [you]77-bennet that , [[my]320-the old archer master]3094-my master . [I]320-the old archer am [an old man]3155-an old man , and draw fast to homeward , where the bed is ready . "[320-the old archer]

" [Y]77-bennet are [the shrewishest old dolt in [Tunstall Forest]12-tunstall forest]3157-the shrewishest old dolt in tunstall forest , "[77-bennet] returned [Hatch]77-bennet , visibly ruffled by these threats . " Get [ye]77-bennet to [your]77-bennet arms before [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver come , and leave prating for one good while . An [ye]77-bennet had talked so much with [Harry the Fift]83-harry the fift , [his]83-harry the fift ears would ha been richer than [his]83-harry the fift pocket . "[77-bennet]

An arrow sang in the air , like a huge hornet ; it struck [old Appleyard]84-appleyard between the shoulder - blades , and pierced [him]84-appleyard clean through , and [he]84-appleyard fell forward on [his]84-appleyard face among the cabbages . [Hatch]77-bennet , with a broken cry , leapt into the air ; then , stooping double , [he]77-bennet ran for the cover of [the house]321-the house . And in the meanwhile [Dick Shelton]76-dick had dropped behind a lilac , and had [his]76-dick crossbow bent and shouldered , covering the point of [the forest]246-the forest .

Not a leaf stirred . [The sheep]323-the sheep were patiently browsing ; the birds had settled . But there lay [the old man]324-the old man , with a cloth - yard arrow standing in [his]324-the old man back ; and there were [Hatch]77-bennet holding to the gable , and [Dick]76-dick crouching and ready behind the lilac bush .

" D [ye]76-dick see aught ? "[77-bennet] cried [Hatch]77-bennet .

" Not a twig stirs , "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick .

" [I]77-bennet think shame to leave [him]324-the old man lying , "[77-bennet] said [Bennet]77-bennet , coming forward once more with hesitating steps and a very pale countenance . " Keep a good eye on the wood , [Master Shelton]74-master shelton keep a clear eye on [the wood]3158-the wood . [The saints]3104-the saints assoil [us]3160-us ! here was a good shoot ! "[77-bennet]

[Bennet]77-bennet raised [the old archer]320-the old archer on [his]77-bennet knee . [He]320-the old archer was not yet dead ; [his]320-the old archer face worked , and [his]320-the old archer eyes shut and opened like machinery , and [he]320-the old archer had a most horrible , ugly look of one in pain .

" Can [ye]76-dick hear , [old Nick]84-appleyard ? "[77-bennet] asked [Hatch]77-bennet . " Have [ye]76-dick a last wish before [ye]76-dick wend , [old brother]3161-old brother ? "[77-bennet]

" Pluck out the shaft , and let [me]84-appleyard pass , a [Mary]93-mary s name ! "[84-appleyard] gasped [Appleyard]84-appleyard . " [I]84-appleyard be done with [Old England]94-old england . Pluck it out ! "[84-appleyard]

" [Master Dick]76-dick , "[77-bennet] said [Bennet]77-bennet , " come hither , and pull [me]77-bennet a good pull upon the arrow . [He]320-the old archer would fain pass , [the poor sinner]3162-the poor sinner . "[77-bennet]

[Dick]76-dick laid down [his]76-dick cross - bow , and pulling hard upon the arrow , drew it forth . A gush of blood followed ; [the old archer]320-the old archer scrambled half upon [his]320-the old archer feet , called once upon the name of [God]79-god , and then fell dead . [Hatch]77-bennet , upon [his]77-bennet knees among the cabbages , prayed fervently for the welfare of [the passing spirit]327-the passing spirit . But even as [he]77-bennet prayed , it was plain that [his]77-bennet mind was still divided , and [he]77-bennet kept ever an eye upon the corner of the wood from which the shot had come . When [he]77-bennet had done , [he]77-bennet got to [his]77-bennet feet again , drew off one of [his]77-bennet mailed gauntlets , and wiped [his]77-bennet pale face , which was all wet with terror .

" Ay , "[77-bennet] [he]77-bennet said , " it ll be [my]77-bennet turn next . "[77-bennet]

"[329-the retainer]

[They]330-they took up [the old archer]320-the old archer , and carried [him]320-the old archer between [them]330-they into [[his]320-the old archer house]3170-his house , where [he]320-the old archer had dwelt alone . And there [they]330-they laid [him]320-the old archer on the floor , out of regard for the mattress , and sought , as best [they]330-they might , to straighten and compose [his]320-the old archer limbs .

[[Appleyard]84-appleyard s house]333-appleyard s house was clean and bare . There was a bed , with a blue cover , a cupboard , a great chest , a pair of joint - stools , a hinged table in the chimney corner , and hung upon the wall [the old soldier]307-the old soldier s armoury of bows and defensive armour . [Hatch]77-bennet began to look about [him]320-the old archer curiously .

" [Nick]84-appleyard had money , "[77-bennet] [he]77-bennet said . " [He]84-appleyard may have had three score pounds put by . [I]77-bennet would [I]77-bennet could light upon t ! [He]84-appleyard had a strong hand to get , and a hard hand to keep withal , had [Appleyard]84-appleyard [the archer]3173-the archer . Now may [God]79-god rest [his]84-appleyard spirit ! Near eighty year [he]84-appleyard was afoot and about , and ever getting ; but now [he]84-appleyard s on the broad of [his]84-appleyard back , poor shrew , and no more lacketh ; and if [his]84-appleyard chattels came to [a good friend]3174-a good friend , [he]84-appleyard would be merrier , methinks , in heaven . [Hatch]77-bennet made several signs of the cross ; but by this time [his]77-bennet natural complexion had returned , and [he]77-bennet was not easily to be dashed from any purpose . " [Appleyard]84-appleyard "[337-the newcomer] [the newcomer]337-the newcomer was saying , as [he]337-the newcomer entered ; but [he]337-the newcomer stopped dead . " [Ave Maria]96-ave maria ! " An t please [you]338-the priest , [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver , "[77-bennet] said [Bennet]77-bennet , " the axles are so hot in [this country]3189-this country that [I]77-bennet have long been smelling fire . So did [this poor sinner]3190-this poor sinner , [Appleyard]84-appleyard . And , by [your]77-bennet leave , [men s spirits]3191-men s spirits are so foully inclined to all of [us]3192-us , that it needs neither [York]8-york nor [Lancaster]7-lancaster to spur [them]3191-men s spirits on . Hear [my]77-bennet plain thoughts : [You]77-bennet , that are [a clerk]3193-a clerk , and [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , that sails on any wind , [ye]77-bennet have taken [many men]3194-many men s goods , and beaten and hanged not a few . [Y]77-bennet are called to count for this ; in the end , [I]77-bennet wot not how , [ye]77-bennet have ever the uppermost at law , and [ye]77-bennet think all patched . But give [me]77-bennet leave , [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver : [the man that [ye]77-bennet have dispossessed and beaten]3195-the man that ye have dispossessed and beaten is but the angrier , and some day , when [the black devil]3196-the black devil is by , [he]3196-the black devil will up with [his]3196-the black devil bow and clout [me]77-bennet a yard of arrow through [your]77-bennet inwards . "[77-bennet]

" [Y]77-bennet are [a prater]3197-a prater , [Bennet]77-bennet , [a talker]3198-a talker , [a babbler]3199-a babbler ; [your]77-bennet mouth is wider than [your]77-bennet two ears . [The priest]338-the priest now rose from the stool , and from the writing - case that hung about [his]338-the priest neck took forth wax and a taper , and a flint and steel . With these [he]338-the priest sealed up the chest and the cupboard with [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel s arms , [Hatch]77-bennet looking on disconsolate ; and then [the whole party]343-the whole party proceeded , somewhat timorously , to sally from [the house]321-the house and get to horse .

" Tis time [we]343-the whole party were on [the road]257-the road , [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver , "[77-bennet] said [Hatch]77-bennet , as [he]77-bennet held [the priest]338-the priest s stirrup while [he]77-bennet mounted .

" Ay ; but , [Bennet]77-bennet , things are changed , "[346-the parson] returned [the parson]346-the parson . " There is now no [Appleyard]84-appleyard rest [his]338-the priest soul ! to keep [the garrison]3201-the garrison . [I]346-the parson shall keep [you]77-bennet , [Bennet]77-bennet . [I]346-the parson must have [a good man]3202-a good man to rest [me]346-the parson on in this day of black arrows . The arrow that flieth by day , saith [the evangel]3203-the evangel ; [I]346-the parson have no mind of the context ; nay , [I]346-the parson am [a sluggard priest]3204-a sluggard priest , [I]346-the parson am too deep in [men]3205-men s affairs . Well , let [us]347-they ride forth , [Master Hatch]85-master hatch . [The jackmen]3206-the jackmen should be at [the church]262-the church by now . "[346-the parson]

So [they]347-they rode forward down [the road]257-the road , with the wind after [them]347-they , blowing the tails of [the parson]346-the parson s cloak ; and behind [them]347-they , as [they]347-they went , clouds began to arise and blot out the sinking sun . [They]347-they had passed [three of [the scattered houses that make up [Tunstall hamlet]5-tunstall]351-the scattered houses that make up tunstall hamlet]350-three of the scattered houses that make up tunstall hamlet , when , coming to a turn , [they]347-they saw [the church]262-the church before [them]347-they . [Ten or a dozen houses]353-ten or a dozen houses clustered immediately round [it]262-the church ; but to the back [the churchyard]354-the churchyard was next [the meadows]318-the meadows . At the lych - gate , near [a score of [men]3205-men]356-a score of men were gathered , some in the saddle , some standing by [their]358-their horses heads . [They]356-a score of men were variously armed and mounted ; [some with spears]359-some with spears , [some with bills]360-some with bills , [some with bows]361-some with bows , and [some bestriding plough - horses]362-some bestriding plough - horses , still splashed with the mire of the furrow ; for these were the very dregs of [the country]363-the country , and [all the better men]364-all the better men and [the fair equipments]365-the fair equipments were already with [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel in [the field]306-the field .

" [We]3208-we have not done amiss , praised be the cross of [Holywood]14-holywood ! [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel will be right well content , "[338-the priest] observed [the priest]338-the priest , inwardly numbering [the troop]368-the troop .

" Who goes ? Stand ! if [ye]3209-ye be true ! "[77-bennet] shouted [Bennet]77-bennet . [A man]3107-a man was seen slipping through [the churchyard]354-the churchyard among the yews ; and at the sound of this summons [he]3107-a man discarded all concealment , and fairly took to [his]3107-a man heels for [the forest]246-the forest . [The men at the gate , who had been hitherto unaware of [the stranger s presence]373-the stranger s presence]372-the men at the gate , who had been hitherto unaware of the stranger s presence , woke and scattered . [Those who had dismounted]374-those who had dismounted began scrambling into the saddle ; [the rest]375-the rest rode in pursuit ; but [they]375-the rest had to make the circuit of [the consecrated ground]376-the consecrated ground , and it was plain [[their]375-the rest quarry]377-their quarry would escape [them]375-the rest . [Hatch]77-bennet , roaring an oath , put [his]77-bennet horse at the hedge , to head [him]377-their quarry off ; but the beast refused , and sent [his]77-bennet rider sprawling in the dust . And though [he]377-their quarry was up again in a moment , and had caught the bridle , the time had gone by , and [the fugitive]378-the fugitive had gained too great a lead for any hope of capture .

The wisest of all had been [Dick Shelton]76-dick . Instead of starting in a vain pursuit , [he]377-their quarry had whipped [his]377-their quarry crossbow from [his]377-their quarry back , bent it , and set a quarrel to the string ; and now , when [the others]379-the others had desisted , [he]377-their quarry turned to [Bennet]77-bennet and asked if [he]77-bennet should shoot .

" Shoot ! shoot ! "[338-the priest] cried [the priest]338-the priest , with sanguinary violence .

" Cover [him]3175-the man , [Master Dick]76-dick , "[77-bennet] said [Bennet]77-bennet . " Bring [me]77-bennet [him]3175-the man down like a ripe apple . "[77-bennet]

[The fugitive]378-the fugitive was now within but a few leaps of safety ; but [this last part of [the meadow]383-the meadow]382-this last part of the meadow ran very steeply uphill ; and [the man]3175-the man ran slower in proportion . What with the greyness of the falling night , and the uneven movements of [the runner]385-the runner , it was no easy aim ; and as [Dick]76-dick levelled [his]76-dick bow , [he]76-dick felt a kind of pity , and a half desire that [he]76-dick might miss . The quarrel sped .

[The man]3175-the man stumbled and fell , and a great cheer arose from [Hatch]77-bennet and [the pursuers]387-the pursuers . But [they]388-they were counting [their]388-they corn before the harvest . [The man]3175-the man fell lightly ; [he]3175-the man was lightly afoot again , turned and waved [his]3175-the man cap in a bravado , and was out of sight next moment in the margin of the wood .

" And the plague go with [him]3175-the man ! "[77-bennet] cried [Bennet]77-bennet . " [He]3175-the man has thieves heels ; [he]3175-the man can run , by [St Banbury]15-st banbury ! But [you]73-sir oliver touched [him]3175-the man , [Master Shelton]74-master shelton ; [he]3175-the man has stolen [your]73-sir oliver quarrel , may [he]3175-the man never have good [I]77-bennet grudge [him]3175-the man less ! "[77-bennet]

" Nay , but what made [he]3175-the man by [the church]262-the church ? "[73-sir oliver] asked [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver . " [I]73-sir oliver am shrewdly afeared there has been mischief here . [Clipsby]80-clipsby , [good fellow]3211-good fellow , get [ye]3211-good fellow down from [your]3211-good fellow horse , and search thoroughly among the yews . "[73-sir oliver]

[Clipsby]80-clipsby was gone but a little while ere [he]73-sir oliver returned carrying a paper .

" This writing was pinned to the church door , "[73-sir oliver] [he]73-sir oliver said , handing it to [the parson]346-the parson . " [I]73-sir oliver found naught else , [sir parson]3178-sir parson . "[73-sir oliver]

" Now , by the power of [Mother Church]16-mother church , "[73-sir oliver] cried [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver , " but this runs hard on sacrilege ! For [the king]3103-the king s good pleasure , or [the lord of the manor]3214-the lord of the manor well ! But that every run - the - hedge in a green jerkin should fasten papers to the chancel door nay , it runs hard on sacrilege , hard ; and [men]3205-men have burned for matters of less weight . But what have [we]3216-we here ? The light falls apace . [Good Master Richard]74-master shelton , [y]74-master shelton have young eyes . Read [me]73-sir oliver , [I]73-sir oliver pray , this libel . "[73-sir oliver]

[Dick Shelton]76-dick took the paper in [his]76-dick hand and read it aloud . It contained some lines of very rugged doggerel , hardly even rhyming , written in a gross character , and most uncouthly spelt . With the spelling somewhat bettered , this is how [they]391-i ran :

" [I]391-i had four blak arrows under [my]391-i belt , Four for the greefs that [I]391-i have felt , Four for [the nomber of ill menne That have opressid [me]391-i now and then]3217-the nomber of ill menne that have opressid me now and then .[391-i]

One is gone ; one is [wele]392-wele sped ; Old Apulyaird is ded .

One is for [Maister Bennet Hatch]77-bennet , That burned Grimstone , walls and thatch .

One for [Sir Oliver Oates]73-sir oliver , That cut [Sir Harry Shelton]105-harry shelton s throat .

[Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , [ye]72-sir daniel shull have the fourt ; [We]393-we shall think it fair sport .

[Ye]72-sir daniel shull each have [your]72-sir daniel own part , A blak arrow in each blak heart . Get [ye]72-sir daniel to [your]72-sir daniel knees for to pray : [Ye]72-sir daniel are ded [theeves]394-theeves , by [yea]395-yea and nay !

" [Jon Amend]106-jon amend - All of the Green Wood , And [his]106-jon amend jolly fellaweship .[395-yea]

" Item , [we]393-we have mo arrowes and goode hempen cord for otheres of [your]72-sir daniel following . "[395-yea]

" Now , well - a - day for charity and the Christian graces ! "[73-sir oliver] cried [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver , lamentably . " [Sirs]3179-sirs , this is [an ill world]3219-an ill world , and groweth daily worse . [I]73-sir oliver will swear upon the cross of [Holywood]14-holywood [I]73-sir oliver am as innocent of [that good knight]3220-that good knight s hurt , whether in act or purpose , as [the babe unchristened]3221-the babe unchristened . Neither was [his]3220-that good knight throat cut ; for therein [they]3222-they are again in error , as there still live [credible witnesses to show]3223-credible witnesses to show . "[73-sir oliver]

" It boots not , [sir parson]3178-sir parson , "[77-bennet] said [Bennet]77-bennet . " Here is unseasonable talk . "[77-bennet]

" Nay , [Master Bennet]87-master bennet , not so . Keep [ye]87-master bennet in [your]87-master bennet due place , [good Bennet]87-master bennet , "[338-the priest] answered [the priest]338-the priest . " [I]338-the priest shall make [mine]338-the priest innocence appear . [I]338-the priest will , upon no consideration , lose [my]338-the priest poor life in error . [I]338-the priest was sent of an errand before nine upon the clock "[338-the priest]

" [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver , "[77-bennet] said [Hatch]77-bennet , interrupting , " since it please [you]73-sir oliver not to stop this sermon , [I]77-bennet will take other means . Goffe , sound to horse . "[77-bennet]

And while the tucket was sounding , [Bennet]77-bennet moved close to [the bewildered parson]397-the bewildered parson , and whispered violently in [his]397-the bewildered parson ear .

[Dick Shelton]76-dick saw [the priest]338-the priest s eye turned upon [him]338-the priest for an instant in a startled glance . [He]76-dick had some cause for thought ; for this [Sir Harry Shelton]105-harry shelton was [[his]105-harry shelton own natural father]399-his own natural father . But [he]105-harry shelton said never a word , and kept [his]105-harry shelton countenance unmoved .

[Hatch]77-bennet and [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver discussed together for a while [their]400-their altered situation ; [ten men]401-ten men , it was decided between [them]400-their , should be reserved , not only to garrison [the Moat House]260-the moat house , but to escort [the priest]338-the priest across [the wood]3158-the wood . In the meantime , as [Bennet]77-bennet was to remain behind , the command of the reinforcement was given to [Master Shelton]74-master shelton . Indeed , there was no choice ; [the men]405-the men were loutish fellows , dull and unskilled in war , while [Dick]76-dick was not only popular , but resolute and grave beyond [his]76-dick age . Although [his]76-dick youth had been spent in these rough , country places , [the lad]309-the lad had been well taught in letters by [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver , and [Hatch]77-bennet [himself]77-bennet had shown [him]309-the lad the management of arms and the first principles of command . [Bennet]77-bennet had always been kind and helpful ; [he]77-bennet was one of those who are cruel as the grave to [those [they]408-their call [[their]408-their enemies]409-their enemies , but ruggedly faithful and well willing to [[their]408-their friends]410-their friends]407-those they call their enemies , but ruggedly faithful and well willing to their friends ; and now , while [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver entered [the next house]411-the next house to write , in [his]73-sir oliver swift , exquisite penmanship , a memorandum of the last occurrences to [[his]73-sir oliver master]292-his master , [Sir Daniel Brackley]72-sir daniel , [Bennet]77-bennet came up to [[his]77-bennet pupil]413-his pupil to wish [him]413-his pupil [God]79-god - speed upon [his]413-his pupil enterprise .

" [Ye]413-his pupil must go the long way about , [Master Shelton]74-master shelton , "[77-bennet] [he]77-bennet said ; " round by [the bridge]265-the bridge , for [your]413-his pupil life ! Keep [a sure man]3227-a sure man fifty paces afore [you]413-his pupil , to draw shots ; and go softly till [y]413-his pupil are past [the wood]3158-the wood . If the rogues fall upon [you]413-his pupil , ride for t ; [ye]413-his pupil will do naught by standing . And keep ever forward , [Master Shelton]74-master shelton ; turn [me]77-bennet not back again , an [ye]413-his pupil love [your]413-his pupil life ; there is no help in [Tunstall]5-tunstall , mind [ye]413-his pupil that . And now , since [ye]413-his pupil go to the great wars about [the king]3103-the king , and [I]77-bennet continue to dwell here in extreme jeopardy of [my]77-bennet life , and [the saints]3104-the saints alone can certify if [we]3231-we shall meet again below , [I]77-bennet give [you]413-his pupil [my]77-bennet last counsels now at [your]413-his pupil riding . Keep an eye on [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel ; [he]72-sir daniel is unsure . Put not [your]413-his pupil trust in [the jack - priest]3232-the jack - priest ; [he]72-sir daniel intendeth not amiss , but doth the will of [others]237-others ; it is a hand - gun for [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel ! Get [[your]413-his pupil good lordship]3234-your good lordship where [ye]413-his pupil go ; make [you]413-his pupil [strong friends]3235-strong friends ; look to it . And think ever a pater - noster - while on [Bennet Hatch]77-bennet . There are worse rogues afoot than [Bennet]77-bennet . So , [God]79-god - speed ! "[77-bennet]

" And Heaven be with [you]77-bennet , [Bennet]77-bennet ! "[76-dick] returned [Dick]76-dick . " [Ye]77-bennet were [a good friend to [me]76-dick - ward]3236-a good friend to me - ward , and so [I]76-dick shall say ever . "[76-dick]

" And , look [ye]77-bennet , [master]3237-master , "[77-bennet] added [Hatch]77-bennet , with a certain embarrassment , " if [this Amend - All]3238-this amend - all should get a shaft into [me]77-bennet , [ye]77-bennet might , mayhap , lay out a gold mark or mayhap a pound for [my]77-bennet poor soul ; for it is like to go stiff with [me]77-bennet in purgatory . "[77-bennet]

" [Ye]77-bennet shall have [your]77-bennet will of it , [Bennet]77-bennet , "[76-dick] answered [Dick]76-dick . " But , what cheer , [man]3147-man ! [we]3240-we shall meet again , where [ye]77-bennet shall have more need of ale than [masses]3241-masses . "[76-dick]

" [The saints]3104-the saints so grant it , [Master Dick]76-dick ! "[311-the other] returned [the other]311-the other . " But here comes [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver . An [he]73-sir oliver were as quick with the long - bow as with the pen , [he]73-sir oliver would be [a brave man - at - arms]3243-a brave man - at - arms . "[311-the other]

[Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver gave [Dick]76-dick a sealed packet , with this superscription : " To [[my]76-dick ryght worchypful master]3244-my ryght worchypful master , [Sir Daniel Brackley]72-sir daniel , knyght , be thys delyvered in haste . "[76-dick]

And [Dick]76-dick , putting it in the bosom of [his]76-dick jacket , gave the word and set forth westward up [the village]261-the village .

BOOK [I]0-i [THE TWO LADS]416-the two lads

CHAPTER [I]0-i AT THE SIGN OF THE SUN IN [KETTLEY

Sir Daniel]75-sir daniel and [[his]75-sir daniel men]417-his men lay in and about [Kettley]75-sir daniel that night , warmly quartered and well patrolled . But [the Knight of Tunstall]418-the knight of tunstall was [one who never rested from money - getting]419-one who never rested from money - getting ; and even now , when [he]418-the knight of tunstall was on the brink of an adventure which should make or mar [him]418-the knight of tunstall , [he]418-the knight of tunstall was up an hour after midnight to squeeze [poor neighbours]420-poor neighbours . [He]418-the knight of tunstall was one who trafficked greatly in disputed inheritances ; it was [his]418-the knight of tunstall way to buy out [the most unlikely claimant]421-the most unlikely claimant , and then , by the favour [he]418-the knight of tunstall curried with [great lords about [the king]3103-the king]422-great lords about the king , procure unjust decisions in [his]418-the knight of tunstall favour ; or , if that was too roundabout , to seize [the disputed manor]424-the disputed manor by force of arms , and rely on [his]418-the knight of tunstall influence and [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver s cunning in the law to hold what [he]418-the knight of tunstall had snatched . [Kettley]75-sir daniel was [one such place]425-one such place ; it had come very lately into [his]418-the knight of tunstall clutches ; [he]418-the knight of tunstall still met with opposition from [the tenants]426-the tenants ; and it was to overawe discontent that [he]418-the knight of tunstall had led [[his]418-the knight of tunstall troops]427-his troops that way .

By two in the morning , [Sir Daniel]75-sir daniel sat in [the inn room]428-the inn room , close by the fireside , for it was cold at that hour among [the fens of [Kettley]75-sir daniel]429-the fens of kettley . By [his]75-sir daniel elbow stood a pottle of spiced ale . [He]75-sir daniel had taken off [his]75-sir daniel visored headpiece , and sat with [his]75-sir daniel bald head and thin , dark visage resting on one hand , wrapped warmly in a sanguine - coloured cloak . At the lower end of [the room]430-the room about a dozen of [[his]75-sir daniel men]417-his men stood sentry over the door or lay asleep on benches ; and somewhat nearer hand , [a young lad , apparently of twelve or thirteen]432-a young lad , apparently of twelve or thirteen , was stretched in a mantle on the floor . [The host of the Sun]433-the host of the sun stood before [the great man]434-the great man .

" Now , mark [me]75-sir daniel , [[mine]75-sir daniel host]3245-mine host , "[75-sir daniel] [Sir Daniel]75-sir daniel said , " follow but [mine]75-sir daniel orders , and [I]75-sir daniel shall be [[your]3245-mine host good lord]3246-your good lord ever . [I]75-sir daniel must have [good men]3247-good men for [head boroughs]3248-head boroughs , and [I]75-sir daniel will have [[Adam]107-adam - a - More high constable]3249-adam - a - more high constable ; see to it narrowly . If [other men]3250-other men be chosen , it shall avail [you]3245-mine host nothing ; rather it shall be found to [your]3245-mine host sore cost . For those that have paid rent to [Walsingham]19-walsingham [I]75-sir daniel shall take good measure [you]3245-mine host among the rest , [[mine]75-sir daniel host]3245-mine host . "[75-sir daniel]

" [Good knight]3252-good knight , "[435-the host] said [the host]435-the host , " [I]435-the host will swear upon the cross of [Holywood]14-holywood [I]435-the host did but pay to [Walsingham]19-walsingham upon compulsion . Nay , [bully knight]3253-bully knight , [I]435-the host love not [the rogue Walsinghams]78-the walsinghams ; [they]78-the walsinghams were as poor as [thieves]3254-thieves , [bully knight]3253-bully knight . Give [me]435-the host [a great lord like [you]3252-good knight]3256-a great lord like you . Nay ; ask [me]435-the host among [the neighbours]3257-the neighbours , [I]435-the host am stout for [Brackley]72-sir daniel . "[435-the host]

" It may be , "[72-sir daniel] said [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , dryly . " [Ye]3252-good knight shall then pay twice . "[72-sir daniel]

[The innkeeper]436-the innkeeper made a horrid grimace ; but this was a piece of bad luck that might readily befall [a tenant]437-a tenant in these unruly times , and [he]436-the innkeeper was perhaps glad to make [his]436-the innkeeper peace so easily .

" Bring up [yon fellow]3258-yon fellow , [Selden]108-selden ! "[438-the knight] cried [the knight]438-the knight .

And [one of [[his]438-the knight retainers]440-his retainers]439-one of his retainers led up [a poor , cringing old man , as pale as a candle , and all shaking with the fen fever]441-a poor , cringing old man , as pale as a candle , and all shaking with the fen fever .

" [Sirrah]109-sirrah , "[72-sir daniel] said [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , " [your]109-sirrah name ? "[72-sir daniel]

" [I]438-the knight have heard [you]109-sirrah ill reported on , "[438-the knight] returned [the knight]438-the knight . How , [fellow]3263-fellow , are [ye]438-the knight so bold ? But [I]438-the knight will bring [you]438-the knight down . "[438-the knight]

" [Right honourable]3264-right honourable and [[my]3175-the man reverend lord]3265-my reverend lord , "[3175-the man] [the man]3175-the man cried , " here is [some hodge - podge]3266-some hodge - podge , saving [your]438-the knight good presence . " [Condall]110-condall , [[my]446-the unfortunate good lord]3271-my good lord ; [Condall]110-condall is [my]446-the unfortunate poor name , "[446-the unfortunate] said [the unfortunate]446-the unfortunate .

" [Condall]110-condall or [Tyndal]111-tyndal , it is all one , "[72-sir daniel] replied [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , coolly . " For , by [my]72-sir daniel sooth , [y]438-the knight are here and [I]72-sir daniel do mightily suspect [your]438-the knight honesty . If [ye]438-the knight would save [your]438-the knight neck , write [me]72-sir daniel swiftly an obligation for twenty pound . "[72-sir daniel]

" For twenty pound , [[my]110-condall good lord]3271-my good lord ! "[110-condall] cried [Condall]110-condall . " Here is midsummer madness ! [My]110-condall whole estate amounteth not to seventy shillings . "[110-condall]

" [Condall]110-condall or [Tyndal]111-tyndal , "[72-sir daniel] returned [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , grinning , " [I]72-sir daniel will run [my]72-sir daniel peril of that loss . "[72-sir daniel]

" Alas ! [[my]110-condall good lord]3271-my good lord , it may not be ; [I]110-condall have no skill to write , "[110-condall] said [Condall]110-condall .

" Well - a - day ! "[438-the knight] returned [the knight]438-the knight . " Here , then , is no remedy . Yet [I]438-the knight would fain have spared [you]438-the knight , [Tyndal]111-tyndal , had [my]438-the knight conscience suffered . [Selden]108-selden , take [me]438-the knight this old shrew softly to the nearest elm , and hang [me]438-the knight [him]111-tyndal tenderly by the neck , where [I]438-the knight may see [him]111-tyndal at [my]438-the knight riding . Fare [ye]438-the knight well , [good Master Condall]110-condall , [dear Master Tyndal]111-tyndal ; [y]438-the knight are post - haste for [Paradise]21-paradise ; fare [ye]438-the knight then well ! "[438-the knight]

" Nay , [[my]110-condall right pleasant lord]3275-my right pleasant lord , "[110-condall] replied [Condall]110-condall , forcing an obsequious smile , " an [ye]438-the knight be so masterful , as doth right well become [you]438-the knight , [I]110-condall will even , with all [my]110-condall poor skill , do [your]438-the knight good bidding . "[110-condall]

" [Friend]3100-friend , "[438-the knight] quoth [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , " [ye]438-the knight will now write two score . Go to ! [y]438-the knight are too cunning for a livelihood of seventy shillings . [Selden]108-selden , see [him]108-selden write [me]72-sir daniel this in good form , and have it duly witnessed . "[72-sir daniel]

And [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , who was [a very merry knight]448-a very merry knight , none merrier in [England]22-england , took a drink of [his]72-sir daniel mulled ale , and lay back , smiling .

Meanwhile , [the boy upon the floor]449-the boy upon the floor began to stir , and presently sat up and looked about [him]449-the boy upon the floor with a scare .

" Hither , "[72-sir daniel] said [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel ; and as the other rose at [his]72-sir daniel command and came slowly towards [him]72-sir daniel , [he]72-sir daniel leaned back and laughed outright . " By the rood ! "[72-sir daniel] [he]72-sir daniel cried , " [a sturdy boy]3277-a sturdy boy ! "[72-sir daniel]

[The lad]309-the lad flushed crimson with anger , and darted a look of hate out of [his]309-the lad dark eyes . Now that [he]309-the lad was on [his]309-the lad legs , it was more difficult to make certain of [his]309-the lad age . [His]309-the lad face looked somewhat older in expression , but it was as smooth as [a young child]451-a young child s ; and in bone and body [he]309-the lad was unusually slender , and somewhat awkward of gait .

" [Ye]438-the knight have called [me]72-sir daniel , [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , "[72-sir daniel] [he]72-sir daniel said . " Was it to laugh at [my]72-sir daniel poor plight ? "[72-sir daniel]

" Nay , now , let laugh , "[438-the knight] said [the knight]438-the knight . " [Good shrew]3278-good shrew , let laugh , [I]438-the knight pray [you]309-the lad . An [ye]309-the lad could see [yourself]309-the lad , [I]438-the knight warrant [ye]309-the lad would laugh the first . "[438-the knight]

" Well , "[309-the lad] cried [the lad]309-the lad , flushing , " [ye]309-the lad shall answer this when [ye]309-the lad answer for the other . Laugh while yet [ye]309-the lad may ! "[309-the lad]

" Nay , now , [good cousin]3279-good cousin , "[72-sir daniel] replied [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , with some earnestness , " think not that [I]72-sir daniel mock at [you]3279-good cousin , except in mirth , as between kinsfolk and [singular friends]3280-singular friends . [I]72-sir daniel will make [you]3279-good cousin a marriage of a thousand pounds , go to ! and cherish [you]3279-good cousin exceedingly . [I]72-sir daniel took [you]3279-good cousin , indeed , roughly , as the time demanded ; but from henceforth [I]72-sir daniel shall ungrudgingly maintain and cheerfully serve [you]3279-good cousin . [Ye]3279-good cousin shall be [Mrs. Shelton Lady Shelton]112-mrs. shelton lady shelton , by [my]72-sir daniel troth ! for [the lad]309-the lad promiseth bravely . Tut ! [ye]3279-good cousin will not shy for honest laughter ; it purgeth melancholy . [They]3282-they are [no rogues who laugh]3283-no rogues who laugh , [good cousin]3279-good cousin . [Good mine host]3285-good mine host , lay [me]72-sir daniel a meal now for [[my]72-sir daniel cousin]3286-my cousin , [Master John]113-master john . Sit [ye]3279-good cousin down , [sweetheart]3287-sweetheart , and eat . "[72-sir daniel]

" Nay , "[113-master john] said [Master John]113-master john , " [I]113-master john will break no bread . Since [ye]3279-good cousin force [me]113-master john to this sin , [I]113-master john will fast for [my]113-master john soul s interest . But , good [mine]72-sir daniel host , [I]113-master john pray [you]3279-good cousin of courtesy give [me]113-master john a cup of fair water ; [I]113-master john shall be much beholden to [your]3279-good cousin courtesy indeed . "[113-master john]

" [Ye]309-the lad shall have a dispensation , go to ! "[438-the knight] cried [the knight]438-the knight . " Shalt be well shriven , by [my]438-the knight faith ! Content [you]309-the lad , then , and eat . "[438-the knight]

But [the lad]309-the lad was obstinate , drank a cup of water , and , once more wrapping [himself]309-the lad closely in [his]309-the lad mantle , sat in a far corner , brooding .

In an hour or two , there rose a stir in [the village]261-the village of [sentries challenging and the clatter of arms and horses]457-sentries challenging and the clatter of arms and horses ; and then [a troop]458-a troop drew up by [the inn]459-the inn door , and [Richard Shelton]74-master shelton , splashed with mud , presented [himself]74-master shelton upon the threshold .

" Save [you]309-the lad , [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , "[74-master shelton] [he]74-master shelton said .

" How ! [Dickie Shelton]114-dickie shelton ! "[438-the knight] cried [the knight]438-the knight ; and at the mention of [Dick]76-dick s name [the other lad]461-the other lad looked curiously across . " What maketh [Bennet Hatch]77-bennet ? "[461-the other lad]

" Please [you]438-the knight , [sir knight]3288-sir knight , to take cognisance of this packet from [Sir Oliver]73-sir oliver , wherein are all things fully stated , "[74-master shelton] answered [Richard]74-master shelton , presenting [the priest]338-the priest s letter . " And please [you]438-the knight farther , [ye]438-the knight were best make all speed to [Risingham]184-lord risingham ; for on the way hither [we]3289-we encountered one riding furiously with letters , and by [his]73-sir oliver report , [[my]74-master shelton Lord of [Risingham]184-lord risingham]3290-my lord of risingham was sore bested , and lacked exceedingly [your]438-the knight presence . "[74-master shelton]

" How say [you]438-the knight ? Sore bested ? "[438-the knight] returned [the knight]438-the knight . " Nay , then , [we]3289-we will make speed sitting down , good [Richard]74-master shelton . As [the world]235-the world goes in [this poor realm of [England]22-england]3292-this poor realm of england , [he]73-sir oliver that rides softliest rides surest . Delay , [they]465-his new troops say , begetteth peril ; but it is rather this itch of doing that undoes [men]3205-men ; mark it , [Dick]76-dick . But let [me]438-the knight see , first , what cattle [ye]76-dick have brought . [Selden]108-selden , a link here at the door ! "[438-the knight]

And [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel strode forth into [the village street]464-the village street , and , by the red glow of a torch , inspected [[his]72-sir daniel new troops]465-his new troops . [He]72-sir daniel was [an unpopular neighbour]466-an unpopular neighbour and [an unpopular master]467-an unpopular master ; but as [a leader in war]468-a leader in war [he]72-sir daniel was well - beloved by [those who rode behind [his]72-sir daniel pennant]469-those who rode behind his pennant . [His]72-sir daniel dash , [his]72-sir daniel proved courage , [his]72-sir daniel forethought for [the soldiers]470-the soldiers comfort , even [his]72-sir daniel rough gibes , were all to the taste of the bold blades in jack and salet .

" Nay , by the rood ! "[72-sir daniel] [he]72-sir daniel cried , " what poor dogs are these ? Here be [some as crooked as a bow , and some as lean as a spear]3294-some as crooked as a bow , and some as lean as a spear . [Friends]3295-friends , [ye]3295-friends shall ride in the front of the battle ; [I]72-sir daniel can spare [you]3295-friends , [friends]3295-friends . Mark [me]72-sir daniel [this old villain on the piebald]3297-this old villain on the piebald ! [A two - year mutton riding on a hog]3298-a two - year mutton riding on a hog would look more soldierly ! Ha ! [Clipsby]80-clipsby , are [ye]80-clipsby there , [old rat]3299-old rat ? [Y]80-clipsby are [a man [I]72-sir daniel could lose with a good heart]3300-a man i could lose with a good heart ; [ye]80-clipsby shall go in front of all , with a bull s eye painted on [your]80-clipsby jack , to be the better butt for archery ; [sirrah]3301-sirrah , [ye]80-clipsby shall show [me]72-sir daniel the way . "[72-sir daniel]

" [I]80-clipsby will show [you]80-clipsby any way , [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , but the way to change sides , "[80-clipsby] returned [Clipsby]80-clipsby , sturdily .

[Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel laughed a guffaw .

" Why , well said ! "[72-sir daniel] [he]72-sir daniel cried . " Hast a shrewd tongue in [thy]438-the knight mouth , go to ! [I]72-sir daniel will forgive [you]438-the knight for that merry word . [Selden]108-selden , see [them]3302-them fed , both [man and brute]3303-man and brute . "[72-sir daniel]

[The knight]438-the knight re - entered [the inn]459-the inn .

" Now , [[friend]3100-friend [Dick]76-dick]3305-friend dick , "[438-the knight] [he]438-the knight said , " fall to . Here is good ale and bacon . Eat , while that [I]438-the knight read . "[438-the knight]

[Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel opened the packet , and as [he]72-sir daniel read [his]72-sir daniel brow darkened . When [he]72-sir daniel had done [he]72-sir daniel sat a little , musing . Then [he]72-sir daniel looked sharply at [[his]72-sir daniel ward]473-his ward .

" [Dick]76-dick , "[72-sir daniel] said [he]72-sir daniel , " [Y]309-the lad have seen this penny rhyme ? "[72-sir daniel]

[The lad]309-the lad replied in the affirmative .

" It bears [[your]309-the lad father]3306-your father s name , "[438-the knight] continued [the knight]438-the knight ; " and [[our]3307-our poor shrew of [a parson]3309-a parson]3308-our poor shrew of a parson is , by [some mad soul]3310-some mad soul , accused of slaying [him]3309-a parson . "[438-the knight]

" [He]3309-a parson did most eagerly deny it , "[76-dick] answered [Dick]76-dick .

" [He]3309-a parson did ? "[438-the knight] cried [the knight]438-the knight , very sharply . " Heed [him]3309-a parson not . [He]3309-a parson has a loose tongue ; [he]3309-a parson babbles like a jack - sparrow . Some day , when [I]438-the knight may find the leisure , [Dick]76-dick , [I]438-the knight will [myself]438-the knight more fully inform [you]76-dick of these matters . There was one [Duckworth]100-ellis shrewdly blamed for it ; but the times were troubled , and there was no justice to be got . "[438-the knight]

" It befell at [the Moat House]17-the moat house ? "[76-dick] [Dick]76-dick ventured , with a beating at [his]76-dick heart .

" It befell between [the Moat House]260-the moat house and [Holywood]14-holywood , "[72-sir daniel] replied [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , calmly ; but [he]72-sir daniel shot a covert glance , black with suspicion , at [Dick]76-dick s face . " And now , "[438-the knight] added [the knight]438-the knight , " speed [you]76-dick with [your]76-dick meal ; [ye]76-dick shall return to [Tunstall]5-tunstall with a line from [me]438-the knight . "[438-the knight]

[Dick]76-dick s face fell sorely .

" [Prithee]115-prithee , [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , "[438-the knight] [he]438-the knight cried , " send [one of [the villains]3313-the villains]3312-one of the villains ! [I]438-the knight beseech [you]72-sir daniel let [me]438-the knight to the battle . [I]438-the knight can strike a stroke , [I]438-the knight promise [you]72-sir daniel . "[438-the knight]

" [I]72-sir daniel misdoubt it not , "[72-sir daniel] replied [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , sitting down to write . " But here , [Dick]76-dick , is no honour to be won . [I]72-sir daniel lie in [Kettley]75-sir daniel till [I]72-sir daniel have sure tidings of the war , and then ride to join [me]72-sir daniel with [the conqueror]3314-the conqueror . Cry not on cowardice ; it is but wisdom , [Dick]76-dick ; for [this poor realm]3315-this poor realm so tosseth with rebellion , and [the king]3103-the king s name and custody so changeth hands , that [no man]3113-no man may be certain of the morrow . Toss - pot and [Shuttle]24-shuttle - wit run in , but [[my]72-sir daniel Lord Good - Counsel]116-my lord good - counsel sits o one side , waiting . "[72-sir daniel]

With that , [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , turning [his]72-sir daniel back to [Dick]76-dick , and quite at the farther end of the long table , began to write [his]72-sir daniel letter , with [his]72-sir daniel mouth on one side , for this business of the Black Arrow stuck sorely in [his]72-sir daniel throat .

Meanwhile , [young Shelton]74-master shelton was going on heartily enough with [his]74-master shelton breakfast , when [he]74-master shelton felt a touch upon [his]74-master shelton arm , and a very soft voice whispering in [his]74-master shelton ear .

" Make not a sign , [I]478-the voice do beseech [you]74-master shelton , "[478-the voice] said [the voice]478-the voice , " but of [your]74-master shelton charity tell [me]478-the voice the straight way to [Holywood]14-holywood . Beseech [you]74-master shelton , now , [good boy]3318-good boy , comfort [a poor soul in peril and extreme distress]3319-a poor soul in peril and extreme distress , and set [me]478-the voice so far forth upon the way to [my]478-the voice repose . "[478-the voice]

" Take the path by [the windmill]3320-the windmill , "[76-dick] answered [Dick]76-dick , in the same tone ; " it will bring [you]74-master shelton to [Till Ferry]25-till ferry ; there inquire again . "[76-dick]

And without turning [his]74-master shelton head , [he]74-master shelton fell again to eating . But with the tail of [his]74-master shelton eye [he]74-master shelton caught a glimpse of [the young lad called [Master John]113-master john]479-the young lad called master john stealthily creeping from [the room]430-the room .

" Why , "[76-dick] thought [Dick]76-dick , " [he]479-the young lad called master john is a young as [I.]76-dick [Good boy]3318-good boy doth [he]479-the young lad called master john call [me]76-dick ? An [I]76-dick had known , [I]76-dick should have seen [the varlet]3322-the varlet hanged ere [I]76-dick had told [him]479-the young lad called master john . Well , if [he]479-the young lad called master john goes through [the fen]3323-the fen , [I]76-dick may come up with [him]479-the young lad called master john and pull [his]479-the young lad called master john ears . "[76-dick]

Half an hour later , [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel gave [Dick]76-dick the letter , and bade [him]76-dick speed to [the Moat House]260-the moat house . And , again , some half an hour after [Dick]76-dick s departure , [a messenger]482-a messenger came , in hot haste , from [[my]0-i Lord of [Risingham]184-lord risingham]3290-my lord of risingham .

" [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , "[484-the messenger] [the messenger]484-the messenger said , " [ye]72-sir daniel lose great honour , by [my]484-the messenger sooth ! The fight began again this morning ere the dawn , and [we]3324-we have beaten [[their]3325-their van]3326-their van and scattered [their]3325-their right wing . Only the main battle standeth fast . An [we]3324-we had [[your]72-sir daniel fresh men]3327-your fresh men , [we]3324-we should tilt [you]72-sir daniel [them]3327-your fresh men all into [the river]248-the river . What , [sir knight]3288-sir knight ! Will [ye]72-sir daniel be the last ? It stands not with [your]72-sir daniel good credit . "[484-the messenger]

" Nay , "[438-the knight] cried [the knight]438-the knight , " [I]438-the knight was but now upon the march . [Selden]108-selden , sound [me]438-the knight [the tucket]3330-the tucket . [Sir]3184-sir , [I]438-the knight am with [you]3184-sir on the instant . It is not two hours since the more part of [my]438-the knight command came in , [sir messenger]3332-sir messenger . What would [ye]3184-sir have ? Spurring is good meat , but yet it killed [the charger]3333-the charger . Bustle , [boys]3334-boys ! "[438-the knight]

By this time the tucket was sounding cheerily in the morning , and from all sides [[Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel s men]486-sir daniel s men poured into [the main street]487-the main street and formed before [the inn]459-the inn . [They]486-sir daniel s men had slept upon [their]486-sir daniel s men arms , with chargers saddled , and in ten minutes [five - score men - at - arms]489-five - score men - at - arms and [archers , cleanly equipped and briskly disciplined]490-archers , cleanly equipped and briskly disciplined , stood ranked and ready . [The chief part]491-the chief part were in [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel s livery , murrey and blue , which gave the greater show to [their]486-sir daniel s men array . [The best armed]492-the best armed rode first ; and away out of sight , at the tail of the column , came [the sorry reinforcement of the night before]493-the sorry reinforcement of the night before . [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel looked with pride along the line .

" Here be [the lads to serve [you]484-the messenger in a pinch]3335-the lads to serve you in a pinch , "[72-sir daniel] [he]72-sir daniel said .

" [They]3335-the lads to serve you in a pinch are [pretty men]3336-pretty men , indeed , "[484-the messenger] replied [the messenger]484-the messenger . " It but augments [my]484-the messenger sorrow that [ye]484-the messenger had not marched the earlier . "[484-the messenger]

" Well , "[438-the knight] said [the knight]438-the knight , " what would [ye]484-the messenger ? The beginning of a feast and the end of a fray , [sir messenger]3332-sir messenger ; "[72-sir daniel] and [he]72-sir daniel mounted into [his]72-sir daniel saddle . " Why ! how now ! "[72-sir daniel] [he]72-sir daniel cried . " [John]113-master john ! [Joanna]117-joanna ! Nay , by [the sacred rood]3338-the sacred rood ! where is [she]117-joanna ? [Host]3339-host , where is [that girl]3340-that girl ? "[72-sir daniel]

" [Girl]3341-girl , [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel ? "[496-the landlord] cried [the landlord]496-the landlord . " Nay , [sir]3184-sir , [I]496-the landlord saw [no girl]3343-no girl . "[496-the landlord]

" [Boy]3344-boy , then , [dotard]3345-dotard ! "[438-the knight] cried [the knight]438-the knight . " Could [ye]484-the messenger not see it was [a wench]3346-a wench ? [She]3346-a wench in the murrey - coloured mantle [she]3346-a wench that broke [her]3346-a wench fast with water , rogue where is [she]3346-a wench ? "[438-the knight]

" Nay , [the saints]3104-the saints bless [us]3348-us ! [Master John]113-master john , [ye]484-the messenger called [him]113-master john , "[435-the host] said [the host]435-the host . " Well , [I]435-the host thought none evil . [He]113-master john is gone . [I]435-the host saw [him]113-master john [her]3346-a wench [I]435-the host saw [her]3346-a wench in [the stable]3349-the stable a good hour agone ; a was saddling a grey horse . "[435-the host]

" Now , by the rood ! "[72-sir daniel] cried [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , " [the wench]3350-the wench was worth five hundred pound to [me]72-sir daniel and more . "[72-sir daniel]

" [Sir knight]3288-sir knight , "[484-the messenger] observed [the messenger]484-the messenger , with bitterness , " while that [ye]484-the messenger are here , roaring for five hundred pounds , [the realm of [England]22-england]3352-the realm of england is elsewhere being lost and won . "[484-the messenger]

" It is well said , "[72-sir daniel] replied [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel . " [Selden]108-selden , fall [me]72-sir daniel out with [six cross - bowmen]3353-six cross - bowmen ; hunt [me]72-sir daniel [her]3346-a wench down . [I]72-sir daniel care not what it cost ; but , at [my]72-sir daniel returning , let [me]72-sir daniel find [her]3346-a wench at [the Moat House]260-the moat house . Be it upon [your]108-selden head . And now , [sir messenger]3332-sir messenger , [we]3356-we march . "[72-sir daniel]

And [the troop]368-the troop broke into a good trot , and [Selden]108-selden and [[his]108-selden six men]501-his six men were left behind upon [the street of [Kettley]75-sir daniel]502-the street of kettley , with [the staring villagers]503-the staring villagers .

CHAPTER II IN [THE FEN]27-the fen

It was near six in the May morning when [Dick]76-dick began to ride down into [the fen]3323-the fen upon [his]76-dick homeward way . The sky was all blue ; the jolly wind blew loud and steady ; the windmill - sails were spinning ; and the willows over all [the fen]3323-the fen rippling and whitening like a field of corn . [He]76-dick had been all night in the saddle , but [his]76-dick heart was good and [his]76-dick body sound , and [he]76-dick rode right merrily .

[The path]506-the path went down and down into [the marsh]507-the marsh , till [he]76-dick lost sight of all the neighbouring landmarks but [Kettley windmill on [the knoll behind [him]76-dick]509-the knoll behind him]508-kettley windmill on the knoll behind him , and [the extreme top of [Tunstall Forest]12-tunstall forest]510-the extreme top of tunstall forest far before . On either hand there were [great fields of blowing reeds and willows]511-great fields of blowing reeds and willows , pools of water shaking in the wind , and treacherous bogs , as green as emerald , to tempt and to betray [the traveller]512-the traveller . [The path]506-the path lay almost straight through [the morass]514-the morass . [It]506-the path was already very ancient ; [its]506-the path foundation had been laid by [Roman soldiery]515-roman soldiery ; in the lapse of ages much of [it]506-the path had sunk , and every here and there , for a few hundred yards , [it]506-the path lay submerged below [the stagnant waters of [the fen]3323-the fen]516-the stagnant waters of the fen .

About a mile from [Kettley]75-sir daniel , [Dick]76-dick came to one such break in the plain line of causeway , where [the reeds and willows]518-the reeds and willows grew dispersedly like little islands and confused the eye . [The gap]519-the gap , besides , was more than usually long ; it was a place where [any stranger]520-any stranger might come readily to mischief ; and [Dick]76-dick bethought [him]76-dick , with something like a pang , of [the lad whom [he]76-dick had so imperfectly directed]521-the lad whom he had so imperfectly directed . As for [himself]76-dick , one look backward to where the windmill sails were turning black against the blue of heaven one look forward to [the high ground of [Tunstall Forest]12-tunstall forest]522-the high ground of tunstall forest , and [he]76-dick was sufficiently directed and held straight on , the water washing to [his]76-dick horse s knees , as safe as on [a highway]523-a highway .

Half - way across , and when [he]76-dick had already sighted the path rising high and dry upon [the farther side]524-the farther side , [he]76-dick was aware of a great splashing on [his]76-dick right , and saw a grey horse , sunk to its belly in the mud , and still spasmodically struggling . Instantly , as though it had divined the neighbourhood of help , the poor beast began to neigh most piercingly . [It]525-it rolled , meanwhile , a blood - shot eye , insane with terror ; and as it sprawled wallowing in the quag , clouds of stinging insects rose and buzzed about it in the air .

" Alack ! "[76-dick] thought [Dick]76-dick , " can [the poor lad]3357-the poor lad have perished ? There is [his]3357-the poor lad horse , for certain [a brave grey]3358-a brave grey ! Nay , [comrade]3359-comrade , if [thou]3360-thou criest to [me]76-dick so piteously , [I]76-dick will do all [man]3147-man can to help [thee]3360-thou . Shalt not lie there to drown by inches ! "[76-dick]

And [he]76-dick made ready [his]76-dick crossbow , and put a quarrel through [the creature]526-the creature s head .

[Dick]76-dick rode on after this act of rugged mercy , somewhat sobered in spirit , and looking closely about [him]76-dick for any sign of [his]76-dick less happy predecessor in the way . " [I]76-dick would [I]76-dick had dared to tell [him]309-the lad further , "[76-dick] [he]76-dick thought ; " for [I]76-dick fear [he]309-the lad has miscarried in the slough . "[76-dick]

And just as [he]76-dick was so thinking , a voice cried upon [his]76-dick name from the causeway side , and , looking over [his]76-dick shoulder , [he]76-dick saw [the lad]309-the lad s face peering from a clump of reeds .

" Are [ye]309-the lad there ? "[76-dick] [he]76-dick said , reining in . " [Ye]309-the lad lay so close among the reeds that [I]76-dick had passed [you]309-the lad by . [I]76-dick saw [your]309-the lad horse bemired , and put [him]309-the lad from [his]309-the lad agony ; which , by [my]76-dick sooth ! an [ye]309-the lad had been [a more merciful rider]3362-a more merciful rider , [ye]309-the lad had done [yourself]309-the lad . But come forth out of [your]309-the lad hiding . Here be none to trouble [you]309-the lad . "[76-dick]

" Nay , [good boy]3318-good boy , [I]311-the other have no arms , nor skill to use them if [I]311-the other had , "[311-the other] replied [the other]311-the other , stepping forth upon [the pathway]529-the pathway .

" Why call [me]76-dick [boy]3344-boy ? "[76-dick] cried [Dick]76-dick . " [Y]309-the lad are not , [I]76-dick trow , [the elder of [us]3366-us twain]3365-the elder of us twain . "[76-dick]

" [Good Master Shelton]118-good master shelton , "[311-the other] said [the other]311-the other , " prithee forgive [me]76-dick . [I]76-dick have none the least intention to offend . Rather [I]76-dick would in every way beseech [your]309-the lad gentleness and favour , for [I]76-dick am now worse bested than ever , having lost [my]76-dick way , [my]76-dick cloak , and [my]76-dick poor horse . To have a riding - rod and spurs , and never a horse to sit upon ! And before all , "[76-dick] [he]76-dick added , looking ruefully upon [his]76-dick clothes " before all , to be so sorrily besmirched ! "[76-dick]

" Tut ! "[76-dick] cried [Dick]76-dick . " Would [ye]309-the lad mind a ducking ? Blood of wound or dust of travel that s [a man]3107-a man s adornment . "[76-dick]

" Nay , then , [I]309-the lad like [him]3107-a man better plain , "[309-the lad] observed [the lad]309-the lad . " But , prithee , how shall [I]309-the lad do ? [Prithee]115-prithee , [good Master Richard]3368-good master richard , help [me]309-the lad with [your]3368-good master richard good counsel . If [I]309-the lad come not safe to [Holywood]14-holywood , [I]309-the lad am undone . "[309-the lad]

" Nay , "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick , dismounting , " [I]76-dick will give more than counsel . Take [my]76-dick horse , and [I]76-dick will run awhile , and when [I]76-dick am weary [we]532-they shall change again , that so , riding and running , [both]3369-both may go the speedier . "[76-dick]

So the change was made , and [they]532-they went forward as briskly as [they]532-they durst on [the uneven causeway]533-the uneven causeway , [Dick]76-dick with [his]76-dick hand upon the other s knee .

" How call [ye]309-the lad [your]309-the lad name ? "[76-dick] asked [Dick]76-dick .

" Call [me]309-the lad [John Matcham]119-john matcham , "[309-the lad] replied [the lad]309-the lad .

" And what make [ye]309-the lad to [Holywood]14-holywood ? "[76-dick] [Dick]76-dick continued .

" [I]76-dick seek sanctuary from [a man that would oppress [me]76-dick]3370-a man that would oppress me , "[76-dick] was the answer . " [The good Abbot of [Holywood]14-holywood]3371-the good abbot of holywood is a strong pillar to [the weak]3372-the weak . "[76-dick]

" And how came [ye]309-the lad with [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , [Master Matcham]120-matcham ? "[76-dick] pursued [Dick]76-dick .

" Nay , "[311-the other] cried [the other]311-the other , " by the abuse of force ! [He]3370-a man that would oppress me hath taken [me]311-the other by violence from [[my]311-the other own place]3373-my own place ; dressed [me]311-the other in these weeds ; ridden with [me]311-the other till [my]311-the other heart was sick ; gibed [me]311-the other till [I]311-the other could a wept ; and when [certain of [[my]311-the other friends]3375-my friends]3374-certain of my friends pursued , thinking to have [me]311-the other back , claps [me]311-the other in the rear to stand [their]3374-certain of my friends shot ! [I]311-the other was even grazed in the right foot , and walk but lamely . Nay , there shall come a day between [us]3376-us ; [he]3370-a man that would oppress me shall smart for all ! "[311-the other]

" Would [ye]76-dick shoot at the moon with a hand - gun ? "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick . " Tis [a valiant knight]3377-a valiant knight , and hath a hand of iron . An [he]3370-a man that would oppress me guessed [I]76-dick had made or meddled with [your]76-dick flight , it would go sore with [me]76-dick . "[76-dick]

" Ay , [poor boy]3378-poor boy , "[311-the other] returned [the other]311-the other , " [y]3378-poor boy are [[his]3370-a man that would oppress me ward]473-his ward , [I]311-the other know it . By the same token , so am [I]311-the other , or so [he]3370-a man that would oppress me saith ; or else [he]3370-a man that would oppress me hath bought [my]311-the other marriage [I]311-the other wot not rightly which ; but it is some handle to oppress [me]311-the other by . "[311-the other]

" [Boy]3344-boy again ! "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick .

" Nay , then , shall [I]120-matcham call [you]76-dick [girl]3341-girl , good [Richard]74-master shelton ? "[120-matcham] asked [Matcham]120-matcham .

" Never [a girl for [me]76-dick]3382-a girl for me , "[76-dick] returned [Dick]76-dick . " [I]76-dick do abjure [the crew of [them]3383-the crew of them]3383-the crew of them ! "[76-dick]

" [Ye]76-dick speak boyishly , "[311-the other] said [the other]311-the other . " [Ye]76-dick think more of [them]3383-the crew of them than [ye]76-dick pretend . "[311-the other]

" Not [I]76-dick , "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick , stoutly . " [They]3383-the crew of them come not in [my]76-dick mind . [A plague of [them]3383-the crew of them]3384-a plague of them , say [I]76-dick ! Give [me]76-dick to hunt and to fight and to feast , and to live with [jolly foresters]3385-jolly foresters . [I]76-dick never heard of [a maid]3386-a maid yet that was for any service , save one only ; and [she]3386-a maid , poor shrew , was burned for [a witch]3387-a witch and the wearing of men s clothes in spite of nature . "[76-dick]

[Master Matcham]120-matcham crossed [himself]120-matcham with fervour , and appeared to pray .

" What make [ye]120-matcham ? "[76-dick] [Dick]76-dick inquired .

" [I]311-the other pray for [her]3387-a witch spirit , "[311-the other] answered [the other]311-the other , with a somewhat troubled voice .

" For [a witch s spirit]3388-a witch s spirit ? "[76-dick] [Dick]76-dick cried . " But pray for [her]3387-a witch , an [ye]120-matcham list ; [she]3387-a witch was [the best wench in [Europe]28-europe]3389-the best wench in europe , was [this Joan of Arc]3390-this joan of arc . [Old Appleyard]121-appleyard [the archer]3173-the archer ran from [her]3387-a witch , [he]3173-the archer said , as if [she]3387-a witch had been [Mahoun]122-mahoun . " Well , but , good [Master Richard]74-master shelton , "[120-matcham] resumed [Matcham]120-matcham , " an [ye]120-matcham like [maids]3393-maids so little , [y]120-matcham are [no true natural man]3394-no true natural man ; for [God]79-god made [them]3393-maids twain by intention , and brought true love into [the world]235-the world , to be [man]3147-man s hope and [woman]3397-woman s comfort . "[120-matcham]

" Faugh ! "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick . " [Y]120-matcham are [a milk - sopping baby]3398-a milk - sopping baby , so to harp on [women]3399-women . An [ye]120-matcham think [I]76-dick be [no true man]3400-no true man , get down upon the path , and whether at fists , back - sword , or bow and arrow , [I]76-dick will prove [my]76-dick manhood on [your]120-matcham body . "[76-dick]

" Nay , [I]120-matcham am [no fighter]3401-no fighter , "[120-matcham] said [Matcham]120-matcham , eagerly . " [I]120-matcham mean no tittle of offence . [I]120-matcham meant but pleasantry . And if [I]120-matcham talk of [women]3399-women , it is because [I]120-matcham heard [ye]120-matcham were to marry . "[120-matcham]

" [I]76-dick to marry ! "[76-dick] [Dick]76-dick exclaimed . " Well , it is the first [I]76-dick hear of it . And with whom was [I]76-dick to marry ? "[76-dick]

" [One Joan Sedley]117-joanna , "[120-matcham] replied [Matcham]120-matcham , colouring . " It was [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel s doing ; [he]72-sir daniel hath money to gain upon both sides ; and , indeed , [I]120-matcham have heard [the poor wench]3403-the poor wench bemoaning [herself]3403-the poor wench pitifully of the match . " Well ! marriage is like death , it comes to all , "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick , with resignation . " And [she]3403-the poor wench bemoaned [herself]3403-the poor wench ?
