" [I]76-dick pray [Heaven]162-heaven that [Capper]166-capper make good speed ! "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick . " [I]76-dick vow a candle to [St. Mary of Shoreby]167-mary if [he]166-capper come before the hour ! "[76-dick]

" [Y]3960-good master are in a hurry , [Master Dick]76-dick ? "[160-greensheve] asked [Greensheve]160-greensheve .

" Ay , [good fellow]3211-good fellow , "[76-dick] answered [Dick]76-dick ; " for in [that house]3672-that house lieth [[my]76-dick lady]1030-my lady , whom [I]76-dick love , and who should these be that lie about [her]1030-my lady secretly by night ? [Unfriends]3964-unfriends , for sure ! "[76-dick]

" Well , "[160-greensheve] returned [Greensheve]160-greensheve , " an [John]166-capper come speedily , [we]3965-we shall give a good account of [them]3966-they . [They]3966-they are not two score at the outside [I]160-greensheve judge so by the spacing of [[their]3966-they sentries]3967-their sentries and , taken where [they]3966-they are , lying so widely , one score would scatter [them]3966-they like sparrows . And yet , [Master Dick]76-dick , an [she]1030-my lady be in Sir Daniel s power already , it will little hurt that [she]1030-my lady should change into another s. Who should these be ? "[160-greensheve]

" [I]76-dick do suspect [the Lord of [Shoreby]20-shoreby]3968-the lord of shoreby , "[76-dick] [Dick]76-dick replied . " When came [they]3966-they ? "[76-dick]

" [They]3966-they began to come , [Master Dick]76-dick , "[160-greensheve] said [Greensheve]160-greensheve , " about the time [ye]76-dick crossed the wall . [I]160-greensheve had not lain [there]718-there the space of a minute ere [I]160-greensheve marked the first of the knaves crawling round the corner . "[160-greensheve]

The last light had been already extinguished in [the little house]1393-the little house when [they]1394-they were wading in the wash of the breakers , and it was impossible to predict at what moment [the lurking men about the garden wall]1395-the lurking men about the garden wall might make [their]1395-the lurking men about the garden wall onslaught . Of two evils , [Dick]76-dick preferred the least . [He]76-dick preferred that [Joanna]117-joanna should remain under the guardianship of [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel rather than pass into the clutches of [Lord Shoreby]143-lord shoreby ; and [his]76-dick mind was made up , if [the house]321-the house should be assaulted , to come at once to the relief of [the besieged]1397-the besieged .

But the time passed , and still there was no movement . From quarter of an hour to quarter of an hour the same signal passed about the garden wall , as if [the leader]1398-the leader desired to assure [himself]1398-the leader of the vigilance of [[his]1398-the leader scattered followers]1399-his scattered followers ; but in every other particular [the neighbourhood of [the little house]1393-the little house]1400-the neighbourhood of the little house lay undisturbed .

[Presently Dick]168-presently dick s reinforcements began to arrive . The night was not yet old before [nearly a score of [men]3205-men]1402-nearly a score of men crouched beside [him]76-dick in [the gorse]875-the gorse .

Separating these into two bodies , [he]76-dick took the command of the smaller [himself]76-dick , and entrusted the larger to [the leadership of [Greensheve]160-greensheve]1405-the leadership of greensheve .

" Now , [Kit]169-kit , "[76-dick] said [he]76-dick to this last , " take [me]76-dick [[your]169-kit men]3970-your men to the near angle of the garden wall upon [the beach]1341-the beach . Post [them]3970-your men strongly , and wait till that [ye]169-kit hear [me]76-dick falling on upon the other side . It is those upon [the sea front]3972-the sea front that [I]76-dick would fain make certain of , for there will be [the leader]1398-the leader . [The rest]375-the rest will run ; even let [them]3970-your men . And now , [lads]3497-lads , let [no man]3113-no man draw an arrow ; [ye]169-kit will but hurt [friends]3295-friends . Take to the steel , and keep to the steel ; and if [we]3978-we have the uppermost , [I]76-dick promise [every man of [you]169-kit]3979-every man of you [a gold noble]3517-a gold noble when [I]76-dick come to [mine]76-dick estate . "[76-dick]

Out of the odd collection of [broken men]1406-broken men , [thieves]3254-thieves , [murderers]1408-murderers , and [ruined peasantry , whom [Duckworth]100-ellis had gathered together to serve the purposes of [his]100-ellis revenge]1409-ruined peasantry , whom duckworth had gathered together to serve the purposes of his revenge , [some of the boldest and the most experienced in war]1410-some of the boldest and the most experienced in war had volunteered to follow [Richard Shelton]74-master shelton . The service of watching [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel s movements in [the town of]1411-the town of [Shoreby]20-shoreby had from the first been irksome to [their]1410-some of the boldest and the most experienced in war temper , and [they]1410-some of the boldest and the most experienced in war had of late begun to grumble loudly and threaten to disperse . The prospect of a sharp encounter and possible spoils restored [them]1410-some of the boldest and the most experienced in war to good humour , and [they]1410-some of the boldest and the most experienced in war joyfully prepared for battle .

[Their]1410-some of the boldest and the most experienced in war long tabards thrown aside , [they]1410-some of the boldest and the most experienced in war appeared , some in plain green jerkins , and some in stout leathern jacks ; under [their]1410-some of the boldest and the most experienced in war hoods many wore bonnets strengthened by iron plates ; and , for offensive armour , swords , daggers , a few stout boar - spears , and a dozen of bright bills , put [them]1410-some of the boldest and the most experienced in war in a posture to engage [even regular feudal troops]1412-even regular feudal troops . The bows , quivers , and tabards were concealed among the gorse , and the two bands set resolutely forward .

[Dick]76-dick , when [he]76-dick had reached the other side of [the house]321-the house , posted [[his]76-dick six men]501-his six men in a line , about twenty yards from the garden wall , and took position [himself]76-dick a few paces in front . Then [they]501-his six men all shouted with one voice , and closed upon [the enemy]1415-the enemy .

[These , lying widely scattered , stiff with cold , and taken at unawares]1416-these , lying widely scattered , stiff with cold , and taken at unawares , sprang stupidly to [their]1416-these , lying widely scattered , stiff with cold , and taken at unawares feet , and stood undecided . Before [they]501-his six men had time to get [their]501-his six men courage about [them]501-his six men , or even to form an idea of the number and mettle of [[their]501-his six men assailants]1417-their assailants , a similar shout of onslaught sounded in [their]501-his six men ears from the far side of [the enclosure]1350-the enclosure . Thereupon [they]501-his six men gave [themselves]501-his six men up for lost and ran .

In this way [the two small troops of [the men of the Black Arrow]714-the men of the black arrow]1419-the two small troops of the men of the black arrow closed upon [the sea front of the garden wall]1421-the sea front of the garden wall , and took a part of [the strangers]1422-the strangers , as it were , between two fires ; while [the whole of the remainder]1423-the whole of the remainder ran for [their]501-his six men lives in different directions , and were soon scattered in the darkness .

For all that , the fight was but beginning . [[Dick]76-dick s outlaws]1424-dick s outlaws , although [they]1424-dick s outlaws had the advantage of the surprise , were still considerably outnumbered by [the men [they]1424-dick s outlaws had surrounded]1425-the men they had surrounded . The tide had flowed , in the meanwhile ; [the beach]1341-the beach was narrowed to a strip ; and on [this wet field]1427-this wet field , between [the surf]1428-the surf and [the garden wall]1429-the garden wall , there began , in the darkness , a doubtful , furious , and deadly contest .

[The strangers]1422-the strangers were well armed ; [they]1422-the strangers fell in silence upon [[their]1422-the strangers assailants]1417-their assailants ; and the affray became a series of single combats . [Dick]76-dick , who had come first into the mellay , was engaged by three ; the first [he]76-dick cut down at the first blow , but the other two coming upon [him]76-dick , hotly , [he]76-dick was fain to give ground before [their]501-his six men onset . One of these two was [a huge fellow , almost a giant for stature]1432-a huge fellow , almost a giant for stature , and armed with a two - handed sword , which [he]76-dick brandished like a switch . Against [this opponent]1433-this opponent , with [his]76-dick reach of arm and the length and weight of [his]76-dick weapon , [Dick]76-dick and [his]76-dick bill were quite defenceless ; and had the other continued to join vigorously in the attack , [the lad]309-the lad must have indubitably fallen . [This second man]1435-this second man , however , less in stature and slower in [his]1435-this second man movements , paused for a moment to peer about [him]1435-this second man in the darkness , and to give ear to the sounds of the battle .

[The giant]1436-the giant still pursued [his]1436-the giant advantage , and still [Dick]76-dick fled before [him]1436-the giant , spying for [his]1436-the giant chance . Then the huge blade flashed and descended , and [the lad , leaping on one side and running in]1437-the lad , leaping on one side and running in , slashed sideways and upwards with [his]309-the lad bill . A roar of agony responded , and , before [the wounded man]1005-the wounded man could raise [his]1005-the wounded man formidable weapon , [Dick]76-dick , twice repeating [his]76-dick blow , had brought [him]1005-the wounded man to the ground .

The next moment [he]76-dick was engaged , upon more equal terms , with [[his]76-dick second pursuer]1439-his second pursuer . Here there was no great difference in size , and though [the man , fighting with sword and dagger against a bill]1440-the man , fighting with sword and dagger against a bill , and being wary and quick of fence , had a certain superiority of arms , [Dick]76-dick more than made it up by [his]76-dick greater agility on foot . Neither at first gained any obvious advantage ; but [the older man]1441-the older man was still insensibly profiting by the ardour of [the younger]1442-the younger to lead [him]1441-the older man where [he]1441-the older man would ; and presently [Dick]76-dick found that [they]1443-they had crossed the whole width of [the beach]1341-the beach , and were now fighting above the knees in the spume and bubble of the breakers . Here [his]76-dick own superior activity was rendered useless ; [he]76-dick found [himself]76-dick more or less at the discretion of [[his]76-dick foe]1445-his foe ; yet a little , and [he]76-dick had [his]76-dick back turned upon [[his]76-dick own men]1446-his own men , and saw that [this adroit and skilful adversary]1447-this adroit and skilful adversary was bent upon drawing [him]76-dick farther and farther away .

[Dick]76-dick ground [his]76-dick teeth . [He]76-dick determined to decide the combat instantly ; and when the wash of the next wave had ebbed and left them dry , [he]76-dick rushed in , caught a blow upon [his]76-dick bill , and leaped right at the throat of [[his]76-dick opponent]1448-his opponent . [The man]3175-the man went down backwards , with [Dick]76-dick still upon the top of [him]3175-the man ; and the next wave , speedily succeeding to the last , buried [him]3175-the man below a rush of water .

While [he]3175-the man was still submerged , [Dick]76-dick forced [his]76-dick dagger from [his]76-dick grasp , and rose to [his]76-dick feet , victorious .

" Yield [ye]1448-his opponent ! "[76-dick] [he]76-dick said . " [I]76-dick give [you]1448-his opponent life . "[76-dick]

" [I]311-the other yield [me]311-the other , "[311-the other] said [the other]311-the other , getting to [his]311-the other knees . " [Ye]1448-his opponent fight , like [a young man]3981-a young man , ignorantly and foolhardily ; but , by the array of [the saints]3104-the saints , [ye]1448-his opponent fight bravely ! "[311-the other]

[Dick]76-dick turned to [the beach]1341-the beach . The combat was still raging doubtfully in the night ; over the hoarse roar of the breakers steel clanged upon steel , and cries of pain and the shout of battle resounded .

" Lead [me]1452-the conquered knight to [[your]76-dick captain]3983-your captain , [youth]3984-youth , "[1452-the conquered knight] said [the conquered knight]1452-the conquered knight . " It is fit this butchery should cease . "[1452-the conquered knight]

" [Sir]3184-sir , "[76-dick] replied [Dick]76-dick , " so far as [these brave fellows]3986-these brave fellows have [a captain]3987-a captain , [the poor gentleman who here addresses [you]76-dick]3988-the poor gentleman who here addresses you is [he]3988-the poor gentleman who here addresses you . "[76-dick]

" Call off [your]76-dick dogs , then , and [I]311-the other will bid [[my]311-the other villains]3989-my villains hold , "[311-the other] returned [the other]311-the other .

There was something noble both in the voice and manner of [[his]76-dick late opponent]1454-his late opponent , and [Dick]76-dick instantly dismissed all fears of treachery .

" Lay down [your]76-dick arms , [men]3205-men ! "[1455-the stranger knight] cried [the stranger knight]1455-the stranger knight . " [I]1455-the stranger knight have yielded [me]1455-the stranger knight , upon promise of life . "[1455-the stranger knight]

The tone of [the stranger]1456-the stranger was one of absolute command , and almost instantly the din and confusion of [the mellay]1457-the mellay ceased .

" [Lawless]132-lawless , "[76-dick] cried [Dick]76-dick , " are [ye]132-lawless safe ? "[76-dick]

" Ay , "[132-lawless] cried [Lawless]132-lawless , " safe and hearty . "[132-lawless]

" Light [me]76-dick the lantern , "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick .

" Is not [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel here ? "[438-the knight] inquired [the knight]438-the knight .

" [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel ? "[76-dick] echoed [Dick]76-dick . " Now , by the rood , [I]76-dick pray not . [It]3991-it would go ill with [me]76-dick if [he]72-sir daniel were . "[76-dick]

" Ill with [you]1455-the stranger knight , [fair sir]3992-fair sir ? "[311-the other] inquired [the other]311-the other . " Nay , then , if [ye]1455-the stranger knight be not of [[Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel s party]3993-sir daniel s party , [I]311-the other profess [I]311-the other comprehend no longer . Wherefore , then , fell [ye]1455-the stranger knight upon [mine]311-the other ambush ? in what quarrel , [[my]311-the other young and very fiery friend]3994-my young and very fiery friend ? to what earthly purpose ? and , to make a clear end of questioning , to what [good gentleman]3995-good gentleman have [I]311-the other surrendered ? "[311-the other]

But before [Dick]76-dick could answer , a voice spoke in the darkness from close by . [Dick]76-dick could see [the speaker]691-the speaker s black and white badge , and the respectful salute which [he]76-dick addressed to [[his]76-dick superior]1461-his superior .

" [[My]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , "[76-dick] said [he]76-dick , " if [these gentlemen]3997-these gentlemen be unfriends to [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel , it is pity , indeed , [we]3998-we should have been at blows with [them]3997-these gentlemen ; but it were tenfold greater that either [they]3997-these gentlemen or [we]3998-we should linger [here]742-here . [The watchers in [the house]321-the house]4000-the watchers in the house unless [they]4000-the watchers in the house be all dead or deaf have heard [our]3998-we hammering this quarter - hour agone ; instantly [they]4000-the watchers in the house will have signalled to [the town]1301-the town ; and unless [we]3998-we be the livelier in [our]3998-we departure , [we]3998-we are like to be taken , both of [us]3998-we , by [a fresh foe]4003-a fresh foe . "[76-dick]

" [Hawksley]170-hawksley is in the right , "[1462-the lord] added [the lord]1462-the lord . " How please [ye]76-dick , [sir]3184-sir ? Whither shall [we]3998-we march ? "[1462-the lord]

" Nay , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick , " go where [ye]3102-my lord will for [me]76-dick . [I]76-dick do begin to suspect [we]3998-we have some ground of friendship , and if , indeed , [I]76-dick began [our]3998-we acquaintance somewhat ruggedly , [I]76-dick would not churlishly continue . Let [us]3998-we , then , separate , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , [you]3102-my lord laying [your]3102-my lord right hand in [mine]76-dick ; and at the hour and place that [ye]3102-my lord shall name , let [us]3998-we encounter and agree . "[76-dick]

" [Y]3102-my lord are too trustful , [boy]3344-boy , "[311-the other] said [the other]311-the other ; " but this time [your]3344-boy trust is not misplaced . [I]311-the other will meet [you]3344-boy at the point of day at [St. Bride s Cross]41-st. bride s cross . Come , [lads]3497-lads , follow ! "[311-the other]

[The strangers]1422-the strangers disappeared from the scene with a rapidity that seemed suspicious ; and , while [the outlaws]3479-the outlaws fell to the congenial task of rifling the dead bodies , [Dick]76-dick made once more the circuit of the garden wall to examine the front of [the house]321-the house . In a little upper loophole of the roof [he]76-dick beheld a light set ; and as it would certainly be visible in [town]3118-town from the back windows of [[Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel s mansion]1468-sir daniel s mansion , [he]76-dick doubted not that this was the signal feared by [Hawksley]170-hawksley , and that ere long the lances of [the Knight of Tunstall]418-the knight of tunstall would arrive upon the scene .

[He]76-dick put [his]76-dick ear to the ground , and it seemed to [him]76-dick as if [he]76-dick heard a jarring and hollow noise from [townward]1470-townward . Back to [the beach]1341-the beach [he]76-dick went hurrying . But the work was already done ; the last body was disarmed and stripped to the skin , and [four fellows]1472-four fellows were already wading seaward to commit it to the mercies of [the deep]1473-the deep .

A few minutes later , when there debauched out of [the nearest lanes of [Shoreby]20-shoreby]1474-the nearest lanes of shoreby [some two score horsemen]1254-some two score horsemen , hastily arrayed and moving at the gallop of [[their]1254-some two score horsemen steeds]1476-their steeds , [the neighbourhood of [the house beside [the sea]1479-the sea]1478-the house beside the sea]1477-the neighbourhood of the house beside the sea was entirely silent and deserted .

Meanwhile , [Dick]76-dick and [[his]76-dick men]417-his men had returned to [the ale - house of the Goat and Bagpipes]1481-the ale - house of the goat and bagpipes to snatch some hours of sleep before the morning tryst .

CHAPTER III [ST . BRIDE S CROSS

St. Bride s cross]1482-st . bride s cross st. bride s cross stood a little way back from [Shoreby]20-shoreby , on [the skirts of [Tunstall Forest]12-tunstall forest]1483-the skirts of tunstall forest . [Two roads]1484-two roads met : one , from [Holywood]14-holywood across [the forest]246-the forest ; one , [that road from [Risingham]184-lord risingham]1486-that road from risingham down which [we]1487-we saw [the wrecks of [a Lancastrian army fleeing in disorder]1489-a lancastrian army fleeing in disorder]1488-the wrecks of a lancastrian army fleeing in disorder . Here [the two]1218-the two joined [issue]1491-issue , and went on together down [the hill]314-the hill to [Shoreby]20-shoreby ; and a little back from [the point of junction]1493-the point of junction , [the summit of [a little knoll]1495-a little knoll]1494-the summit of a little knoll was crowned by the ancient and weather - beaten cross .

Here , then , about seven in the morning , [Dick]76-dick arrived . It was as cold as ever ; [the earth]1496-the earth was all grey and silver with the hoarfrost , and the day began to break in the east with many colours of purple and orange .

[Dick]76-dick set [him]76-dick down upon the lowest step of the cross , wrapped [himself]76-dick well in [his]76-dick tabard , and looked vigilantly upon all sides . [He]76-dick had not long to wait . Down [the road]257-the road from [Holywood]14-holywood [a gentleman in very rich and bright armour , and wearing over that a surcoat of the rarest furs]1498-a gentleman in very rich and bright armour , and wearing over that a surcoat of the rarest furs , came pacing on a splendid charger . Twenty yards behind [him]1498-a gentleman in very rich and bright armour , and wearing over that a surcoat of the rarest furs followed a clump of lances ; but these halted as soon as [they]1499-they came in view of [the trysting - place]1500-the trysting - place , while [the gentleman in the fur surcoat]1501-the gentleman in the fur surcoat continued to advance alone .

[His]1501-the gentleman in the fur surcoat visor was raised , and showed a countenance of great command and dignity , answerable to the richness of [his]1501-the gentleman in the fur surcoat attire and arms . And it was with some confusion of manner that [Dick]76-dick arose from the cross and stepped down [the bank]601-the bank to meet [[his]76-dick prisoner]1503-his prisoner .

" [I]76-dick thank [you]76-dick , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , for [your]76-dick exactitude , "[76-dick] [he]76-dick said , louting very low . " Will it please [[your]76-dick lordship]4010-your lordship to set foot to [earth]3521-earth ? "[76-dick]

" Are [ye]76-dick here alone , [young man]4012-young man ? "[311-the other] inquired [the other]311-the other .

" [I]76-dick was not so simple , "[76-dick] answered [Dick]76-dick ; " and , to be plain with [[your]76-dick lordship]4010-your lordship , [the woods]783-the woods upon either hand of this cross lie full of [[mine]76-dick honest fellows]4015-mine honest fellows lying on [their]4015-mine honest fellows weapons . "[76-dick]

" [Y]76-dick ave done wisely , "[1462-the lord] said [the lord]1462-the lord . " It pleaseth [me]1462-the lord the rather , since last night [ye]76-dick fought foolhardily , and more like [a salvage Saracen lunatic]4016-a salvage saracen lunatic than [any Christian warrior]4017-any christian warrior . But it becomes not [me]1462-the lord to complain that had the undermost . "[1462-the lord]

" [Ye]76-dick had the undermost indeed , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , since [ye]76-dick so fell , "[76-dick] returned [Dick]76-dick ; " but had the waves not holpen [me]76-dick , it was [I]76-dick that should have had the worst . [Ye]76-dick were pleased to make [me]76-dick [yours]76-dick with several dagger marks , which [I]76-dick still carry . And in fine , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , methinks [I]76-dick had all the danger , as well as all the profit , of [that little blind - man]4020-that little blind - man s mellay on [the beach]1341-the beach . "[76-dick]

" [Y]76-dick are shrewd enough to make light of it , [I]1456-the stranger see , "[1456-the stranger] returned [the stranger]1456-the stranger .

" Nay , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , not shrewd , "[76-dick] replied [Dick]76-dick , " in that [I]76-dick shoot at no advantage to [myself]76-dick . But when , by the light of this new day , [I]76-dick see how stout [a knight]4023-a knight hath yielded , not to [my]76-dick arms alone , but to fortune , and the darkness , and the surf and how easily the battle had gone otherwise , with [a soldier so untried and rustic]4024-a soldier so untried and rustic as [myself]76-dick think it not strange , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , if [I]76-dick feel confounded with [my]76-dick victory . "[76-dick]

" [Ye]76-dick speak well , "[1456-the stranger] said [the stranger]1456-the stranger . " [Your]76-dick name ? "[1456-the stranger]

" [My]76-dick name , an t like [you]76-dick , is [Shelton]74-master shelton , "[76-dick] answered [Dick]76-dick .

" [Men]3205-men call [me]311-the other [the Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham , "[311-the other] added [the other]311-the other .

" Then , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , and under [your]76-dick good favour , [ye]76-dick are guardian to [the sweetest maid in [England]22-england]4028-the sweetest maid in england , "[76-dick] replied [Dick]76-dick ; " and for [your]76-dick ransom , and the ransom of such as were taken with [you]76-dick on [the beach]1341-the beach , there will be no uncertainty of terms . [I]76-dick pray [you]76-dick , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , of [your]76-dick goodwill and charity , yield [me]76-dick the hand of [[my]76-dick mistress]4031-my mistress , [Joan Sedley]117-joanna ; and take [ye]76-dick , upon the other part , [your]76-dick liberty , the liberty of [these [your]76-dick followers]4032-these your followers , and if [ye]76-dick will have it [my]76-dick gratitude and service till [I]76-dick die . "[76-dick]

" But are [ye]76-dick not ward to [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel ? Methought , if [y]76-dick are [[Harry Shelton]105-harry shelton s son]4033-harry shelton s son , that [I]157-lord foxham had heard it so reported , "[157-lord foxham] said [Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham .

" Will it please [you]76-dick , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , to alight ? [I]76-dick would fain tell [you]76-dick fully who [I]76-dick am , how situate , and why so bold in [my]76-dick demands . Beseech [you]76-dick , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , take place upon these steps , hear [me]76-dick to a full end , and judge [me]76-dick with allowance . "[76-dick]

And so saying , [Dick]76-dick lent a hand to [Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham to dismount ; led [him]157-lord foxham up [the knoll]1509-the knoll to the cross ; installed [him]157-lord foxham in the place where [he]157-lord foxham had [himself]157-lord foxham been sitting ; and standing respectfully before [[his]157-lord foxham noble prisoner]1510-his noble prisoner , related the story of [his]157-lord foxham fortunes up to the events of the evening before .

[Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham listened gravely , and when [Dick]76-dick had done , " [Master Shelton]74-master shelton , "[76-dick] [he]76-dick said , " [ye]74-master shelton are [a most fortunate - unfortunate young gentleman]4036-a most fortunate - unfortunate young gentleman ; but what fortune [y]74-master shelton ave had , that [ye]74-master shelton have amply merited ; and what unfortune , [ye]74-master shelton have noways deserved . Be of a good cheer ; for [ye]74-master shelton have made [a friend who is devoid neither of power nor favour]4037-a friend who is devoid neither of power nor favour . For [yourself]74-master shelton , although it fits not for [a person of [your]74-master shelton birth]4038-a person of your birth to herd with [outlaws]4039-outlaws , [I]76-dick must own [ye]74-master shelton are both brave and honourable ; very dangerous in battle , right courteous in peace ; [a youth of excellent disposition and brave bearing]4040-a youth of excellent disposition and brave bearing . For [[your]74-master shelton estates]4041-your estates , [ye]74-master shelton will never see them till [the world]235-the world shall change again ; so long as [Lancaster]7-lancaster hath the strong hand , so long shall [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel enjoy them for [his]72-sir daniel own . For [[my]76-dick ward]4043-my ward , it is another matter ; [I]76-dick had promised [her]4043-my ward before to [a gentleman]4044-a gentleman , [a kinsman of [my]76-dick house]4045-a kinsman of my house , [one Hamley]4046-one hamley ; the promise is old "[76-dick]

" Ay , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , and now [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel hath promised [her]4043-my ward to [[my]76-dick Lord]3102-my lord [Shoreby]143-lord shoreby , "[76-dick] interrupted [Dick]76-dick . " And [his]72-sir daniel promise , for all it is but young , is still the likelier to be made good . "[76-dick]

" Tis the plain truth , "[1511-his lordship] returned [[his]76-dick lordship]1511-his lordship . " And considering , moreover , that [I]1511-his lordship am [[your]76-dick prisoner]4049-your prisoner , upon no better composition than [my]1511-his lordship bare life , and over and above that , that [the maiden]4050-the maiden is unhappily in other hands , [I]1511-his lordship will so far consent . Aid [me]1511-his lordship with [[your]76-dick good fellows]4051-your good fellows "[1511-his lordship]

" [[My]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , "[76-dick] cried [Dick]76-dick , " [they]4051-your good fellows are [these same outlaws that [ye]3102-my lord blame [me]76-dick for consorting with]4053-these same outlaws that ye blame me for consorting with . "[76-dick]

" Let [them]4051-your good fellows be what [they]4051-your good fellows will , [they]4051-your good fellows can fight , "[157-lord foxham] returned [Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham . " Help [me]157-lord foxham , then ; and if between [us]4054-us [we]4054-us regain [the maid]4055-the maid , upon [my]157-lord foxham knightly honour , [she]4055-the maid shall marry [you]1503-his prisoner ! "[157-lord foxham]

[Dick]76-dick bent [his]76-dick knee before [[his]76-dick prisoner]1503-his prisoner ; but [he]76-dick , leaping up lightly from the cross , caught [the lad]309-the lad up and embraced [him]309-the lad like [a son]1514-a son .

" Come , "[76-dick] [he]76-dick said , " an [y]1503-his prisoner are to marry [Joan]117-joanna , [we]4056-we must be [early friends]4057-early friends . "[76-dick]

CHAPTER IV THE GOOD HOPE

An hour thereafter , [Dick]76-dick was back at [the Goat and Bagpipes]42-the goat and bagpipes , breaking [his]76-dick fast , and receiving the report of [[his]76-dick messengers]1515-his messengers and sentries . [Duckworth]100-ellis was still absent from [Shoreby]20-shoreby ; and this was frequently the case , for [he]100-ellis played many parts in [the world]235-the world , shared many different interests , and conducted many various affairs . [He]100-ellis had founded [that fellowship of [the Black Arrow]69-the black arrow]1517-that fellowship of the black arrow , as [a ruined man longing for vengeance and money]1518-a ruined man longing for vengeance and money ; and yet among those who knew [him]100-ellis best , [he]100-ellis was thought to be [the agent and emissary of [the great King - maker of [England]22-england]1520-the great king - maker of england , [Richard]74-master shelton , [Earl of [Warwick]43-warwick]1521-earl of warwick]1519-the agent and emissary of the great king - maker of england , richard , earl of warwick .

In [his]74-master shelton absence , at any rate , it fell upon [Richard Shelton]74-master shelton to command affairs in [Shoreby]20-shoreby ; and , as [he]74-master shelton sat at meat , [his]74-master shelton mind was full of care , and [his]74-master shelton face heavy with consideration . It had been determined , between [him]74-master shelton and [the Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham , to make one bold stroke that evening , and , by brute force , to set [Joanna]117-joanna free . The obstacles , however , were many ; and as one after another of [[his]74-master shelton scouts]1522-his scouts arrived , each brought [him]74-master shelton more discomfortable news .

[Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel was alarmed by the skirmish of the night before . [He]72-sir daniel had increased [the garrison of [the house]321-the house in [the garden]3861-the garden]1523-the garrison of the house in the garden ; but not content with that , [he]72-sir daniel had stationed [horsemen]1526-horsemen in all [the neighbouring lanes]1527-the neighbouring lanes , so that [he]72-sir daniel might have instant word of any movement . Meanwhile , in [the court of [[his]72-sir daniel mansion]1529-his mansion]1528-the court of his mansion , steeds stood saddled , and [the riders , armed at every point]1530-the riders , armed at every point , awaited but the signal to ride .

The adventure of the night appeared more and more difficult of execution , till suddenly [Dick]76-dick s countenance lightened .

" [Lawless]132-lawless ! "[76-dick] [he]76-dick cried , " [you]132-lawless that were [a shipman]3491-a shipman , can [ye]132-lawless steal [me]76-dick [a ship]4059-a ship ? "[76-dick]

" [Master Dick]76-dick , "[132-lawless] replied [Lawless]132-lawless , " if [ye]76-dick would back [me]132-lawless , [I]132-lawless would agree to steal [York Minster]44-york minster . "[132-lawless]

Presently after , [these two]1531-these two set forth and descended to [the harbour]1281-the harbour . [It]1281-the harbour was a considerable basin , lying among [sand hills]1533-sand hills , and surrounded with patches of down , ancient ruinous lumber , and [tumble - down slums of [the town]1301-the town]1534-tumble - down slums of the town . [Many decked ships]1536-many decked ships and [many open boats]1537-many open boats either lay there at anchor , or had been drawn up on [the beach]1341-the beach . A long duration of bad weather had driven [them]1531-these two from the high seas into [the shelter of [the port]1540-the port]1539-the shelter of the port ; and the great trooping of black clouds , and the cold squalls that followed one another , now with a sprinkling of dry snow , now in a mere swoop of wind , promised no improvement but rather threatened a more serious storm in the immediate future .

[The seamen , in view of the cold and the wind]1541-the seamen , in view of the cold and the wind , had for the most part slunk ashore , and were now roaring and singing in [the shoreside taverns]1542-the shoreside taverns . [Many of [the ships]1544-the ships]1543-many of the ships already rode unguarded at [their]1543-many of the ships anchors ; and as the day wore on , and the weather offered no appearance of improvement , the number was continually being augmented . It was to [these deserted ships]1545-these deserted ships , and , above all , to those of [them]1545-these deserted ships that lay far out , that [Lawless]132-lawless directed [his]132-lawless attention ; while [Dick]76-dick , seated upon [an anchor that was half embedded in the sand , and giving ear , now to the rude , potent , and boding voices of the gale]1546-an anchor that was half embedded in the sand , and giving ear , now to the rude , potent , and boding voices of the gale , and now to the hoarse singing of [the shipmen]1547-the shipmen in [a neighbouring tavern]1548-a neighbouring tavern , soon forgot [his]76-dick immediate surroundings and concerns in the agreeable recollection of [Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham s promise .

[He]76-dick was disturbed by a touch upon [his]76-dick shoulder . It was [Lawless]132-lawless , pointing to a small ship that lay somewhat by [itself]1549-her , and within but a little of [the harbour mouth]1550-the harbour mouth , where [it]1549-her heaved regularly and smoothly on the entering swell . A pale gleam of winter sunshine fell , at that moment , on the vessel s deck , relieving [her]1549-her against a bank of scowling cloud ; and in this momentary glitter [Dick]76-dick could see [a couple of men hauling [the skiff]1552-the skiff alongside]1551-a couple of men hauling the skiff alongside .

" There , [sir]3184-sir , "[132-lawless] said [Lawless]132-lawless , " mark [ye]3184-sir it well ! There is [the ship]4061-the ship for to - night . "[132-lawless]

Presently [the skiff]1552-the skiff put out from [the vessel]1554-the vessel s side , and [the two men]1555-the two men , keeping [her]1549-her head well to the wind , pulled lustily for [shore]585-shore . [Lawless]132-lawless turned to [a loiterer]1557-a loiterer .

" How call [ye]3184-sir [her]1558-the little vessel ? "[132-lawless] [he]132-lawless asked , pointing to [the little vessel]1558-the little vessel .

" [They]1555-the two men call [her]1558-the little vessel the Good Hope , of [Dartmouth]45-dartmouth , "[1559-the loiterer] replied [the loiterer]1559-the loiterer . " [[Her]1558-the little vessel captain]4062-her captain , [Arblaster]171-skipper arblaster by name . [He]4062-her captain pulleth the bow oar in [yon skiff]4063-yon skiff . "[1559-the loiterer]

This was all that [Lawless]132-lawless wanted . Hurriedly thanking [the man]3175-the man , [he]132-lawless moved round [the shore]1309-the shore to [a certain sandy creek]1562-a certain sandy creek , for which [the skiff]1552-the skiff was heading . There [he]132-lawless took up [his]132-lawless position , and as soon as [they]1564-they were within earshot , opened fire on [the sailors of [the Good Hope]172-the good hope]1565-the sailors of the good hope .

" What ! [Gossip Arblaster]173-arblaster ! "[132-lawless] [he]132-lawless cried . " Why , [ye]3175-the man be well met ; nay , [gossip]4064-gossip , [ye]3175-the man be right well met , upon the rood ! And is that [the Good Hope]4065-the good hope ? Ay , [I]132-lawless would know [her]4065-the good hope among ten thousand ! a sweet shear , [a sweet boat]4066-a sweet boat ! But marry come up , [[my]132-lawless gossip]4067-my gossip , will [ye]3175-the man drink ? [I]132-lawless have come into [[mine]132-lawless estate which doubtless [ye]3175-the man remember to have heard on]4068-mine estate which doubtless ye remember to have heard on . [I]132-lawless am now rich ; [I]132-lawless have left to sail upon [the sea]1479-the sea ; [I]132-lawless do sail now , for the most part , upon spiced ale . Come , [fellow]3263-fellow ; [thy]3175-the man hand upon t ! Come , drink with [an old shipfellow]4071-an old shipfellow ! "[132-lawless]

[Skipper Arblaster]171-skipper arblaster , [a long - faced , elderly , weather - beaten man]1566-a long - faced , elderly , weather - beaten man , with a knife hanging about [his]1566-a long - faced , elderly , weather - beaten man neck by a plaited cord , and for all [the world]235-the world like [any modern seaman in [his]1566-a long - faced , elderly , weather - beaten man gait and bearing]1568-any modern seaman in his gait and bearing , had hung back in obvious amazement and distrust . But the name of [an estate]1569-an estate , and a certain air of tipsified simplicity and good - fellowship which [Lawless]132-lawless very well affected , combined to conquer [his]132-lawless suspicious jealousy ; [his]132-lawless countenance relaxed , and [he]132-lawless at once extended [his]132-lawless open hand and squeezed that of [the outlaw]1231-the outlaw in a formidable grasp .

" Nay , "[132-lawless] [he]132-lawless said , " [I]132-lawless can not mind [you]1571-his follower . But what o that ? [I]132-lawless would drink with [any man]3919-any man , gossip , and so would [[my]132-lawless man]4073-my man [Tom]136-tom . [Man Tom]102-tom , "[132-lawless] [he]132-lawless added , addressing [[his]132-lawless follower]1571-his follower , " here is [[my]132-lawless gossip]4067-my gossip , whose name [I]132-lawless can not mind , but no doubt [a very good seaman]4075-a very good seaman . Let s go drink with [him]4073-my man and [[his]4073-my man shore friend]4076-his shore friend . "[132-lawless]

[Lawless]132-lawless led the way , and [they]1572-they were soon seated in [an alehouse]1573-an alehouse , which , as [it]1573-an alehouse was very new , and stood in an exposed and solitary station , was less crowded than those nearer to [the centre of [the port]1540-the port]1574-the centre of the port . [It]1573-an alehouse was but [a shed of timber]1576-a shed of timber , much like [a blockhouse in [the backwoods of to - day]1578-the backwoods of to - day]1577-a blockhouse in the backwoods of to - day , and was coarsely furnished with a press or two , a number of naked benches , and boards set upon barrels to play the part of tables . In the middle , and besieged by half a hundred violent draughts , a fire of wreck - wood blazed and vomited thick smoke .

" Ay , now , "[132-lawless] said [Lawless]132-lawless , " here is [a shipman]3491-a shipman s joy a good fire and a good stiff cup [ashore]602-ashore , with foul weather without and an off - sea gale a - snoring in the roof ! Here s to [the Good Hope]172-the good hope ! May [she]172-the good hope ride easy ! "[132-lawless]

" Ay , "[171-skipper arblaster] said [Skipper Arblaster]171-skipper arblaster , " tis good weather to be ashore in , that is sooth . [Man Tom]102-tom , how say [ye]102-tom to that ? Gossip , [ye]102-tom speak well , though [I]171-skipper arblaster can never think upon [your]102-tom name ; but [ye]102-tom speak very well . May [the Good Hope]172-the good hope ride easy ! Amen ! "[171-skipper arblaster]

" [Friend Dickon]142-dickon , "[132-lawless] resumed [Lawless]132-lawless , addressing [[his]132-lawless commander]1579-his commander , " [ye]142-dickon have certain matters on hand , unless [I]132-lawless err ? Well , prithee be about [them]4079-them incontinently . For here [I]132-lawless be with the choice of [all good company]4080-all good company , [two tough old shipmen]4081-two tough old shipmen ; and till that [ye]142-dickon return [I]132-lawless will go warrant [these brave fellows]3986-these brave fellows will bide here and drink [me]132-lawless cup for cup . [We]4081-two tough old shipmen are not like [shore - men]4083-shore - men , [we old , tough tarry - Johns]4084-we old , tough tarry - johns ! "[132-lawless]

" It is well meant , "[1580-the skipper] returned [the skipper]1580-the skipper . " [Ye]142-dickon can go , [boy]3344-boy ; for [I]1580-the skipper will keep [[your]142-dickon good friend]4086-your good friend and [my]1580-the skipper good gossip company till curfew ay , and by [St. Mary]167-mary , till the sun get up again ! For , look [ye]142-dickon , when [a man]3107-a man hath been long enough at [sea]3475-sea , the salt getteth [me]1580-the skipper into the clay upon [his]3107-a man bones ; and let [him]3107-a man drink a draw - well , [he]3107-a man will never be quenched . "[1580-the skipper]

Thus encouraged upon all hands , [Dick]76-dick rose , saluted [[his]76-dick company]3710-his company , and going forth again into the gusty afternoon , got [him]76-dick as speedily as [he]76-dick might to the Goat and Bagpipes . Thence [he]76-dick sent word to [[my]0-i Lord]3102-my lord [Foxham]157-lord foxham that , so soon as ever the evening closed , [they]1583-they would have [a stout boat]1584-a stout boat to keep [the sea]1479-the sea in . And then leading along with [him]76-dick [a couple of outlaws who had some experience of]1586-a couple of outlaws who had some experience of [the sea]1479-the sea , [he]76-dick returned [himself]76-dick to [the harbour]1281-the harbour and [the little sandy creek]1589-the little sandy creek .

[The skiff of the Good Hope]1590-the skiff of the good hope lay among many others , from which [it]1590-the skiff of the good hope was easily distinguished by [its]1590-the skiff of the good hope extreme smallness and fragility . Indeed , when [Dick]76-dick and [[his]76-dick two men]1591-his two men had taken [their]1591-his two men places , and begun to put forth out of [the creek]569-the creek into [the open harbour]1593-the open harbour , the little cockle dipped into the swell and staggered under every gust of wind , like a thing upon the point of sinking .

[The Good Hope]172-the good hope , as [we]1594-we have said , was anchored far out , where the swell was heaviest . [No other vessel]1595-no other vessel lay nearer than several cables length ; those that were the nearest were [themselves]1596-themselves entirely deserted ; and as the skiff approached , a thick flurry of snow and a sudden darkening of the weather further concealed the movements of [the outlaws]3479-the outlaws from all possible espial . In a trice [they]3479-the outlaws had leaped upon [the heaving deck]1598-the heaving deck , and [the skiff]1552-the skiff was dancing at the stern . [The Good Hope]172-the good hope was captured .

[She]172-the good hope was [a good stout boat]1600-a good stout boat , decked in the bows and amidships , but open in the stern . [She]172-the good hope carried one mast , and was rigged between a felucca and [a lugger]1601-a lugger . It would seem that [Skipper Arblaster]171-skipper arblaster had made an excellent venture , for [the hold]1602-the hold was full of pieces of French wine ; and in [the little cabin]1603-the little cabin , besides the Virgin Mary in the bulkhead which proved [the captain]1604-the captain s piety , there were many lockfast chests and cupboards , which showed [him]1604-the captain to be rich and careful .

A dog , who was [the sole occupant of [the vessel]1554-the vessel]1605-the sole occupant of the vessel , furiously barked and bit the heels of [the boarders]1607-the boarders ; but [he]1604-the captain was soon kicked into [the cabin]1608-the cabin , and the door shut upon [his]1604-the captain just resentment . A lamp was lit and fixed in the shrouds to mark [the vessel]1554-the vessel clearly from [the shore]1309-the shore ; one of the wine pieces in [the hold]1602-the hold was broached , and a cup of excellent Gascony emptied to the adventure of the evening ; and then , while [one of [the outlaws]3479-the outlaws]1612-one of the outlaws began to get ready [his]1612-one of the outlaws bow and arrows and prepare to hold [the ship]4061-the ship against [all comers]1615-all comers , [the other]311-the other hauled in [the skiff]1552-the skiff and got overboard , where [he]311-the other held on , waiting for [Dick]76-dick .

" Well , [Jack]128-matcham , keep [me]1618-the young commander a good watch , "[1618-the young commander] said [the young commander]1618-the young commander , preparing to follow [[his]1618-the young commander subordinate]1619-his subordinate . " [Ye]128-matcham will do right well . "[1618-the young commander]

" Why , "[128-matcham] returned [Jack]128-matcham , " [I]128-matcham shall do excellent well indeed , so long as [we]4089-we lie here ; but once [we]4089-we put the nose of [this poor ship]4090-this poor ship outside [the harbour]1281-the harbour See , there [she]4090-this poor ship trembles ! Nay , [the poor shrew]4092-the poor shrew heard the words , and the heart misgave [her]4090-this poor ship in [her]4090-this poor ship oak - tree ribs . But look , [Master Dick]76-dick ! how black the weather gathers ! "[128-matcham]

The darkness ahead was , indeed , astonishing . Great billows heaved up out of the blackness , one after another ; and one after another the Good Hope buoyantly climbed , and giddily plunged upon [the further side]1620-the further side . A thin sprinkle of snow and thin flakes of foam came flying , and powdered the deck ; and the wind harped dismally among the rigging .

" In sooth , it looketh evilly , "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick . " But what cheer ! Tis but a squall , and presently it will blow over . "[76-dick] But , in spite of [his]76-dick words , [he]76-dick was depressingly affected by the bleak disorder of the sky and the wailing and fluting of the wind ; and as [he]76-dick got over the side of [the Good Hope]172-the good hope and made once more for [the landing - creek]1621-the landing - creek with the best speed of oars , [he]76-dick crossed [himself]76-dick devoutly , and recommended to [Heaven]162-heaven the lives of [all who should adventure on]1622-all who should adventure on [the sea]1479-the sea .

At [the landing - creek]1621-the landing - creek there had already gathered about [a dozen of [the outlaws]3479-the outlaws]1625-a dozen of the outlaws . To these the skiff was left , and [they]1625-a dozen of the outlaws were bidden embark without delay .

A little further up [the beach]1341-the beach [Dick]76-dick found [Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham hurrying in quest of [him]76-dick , [his]157-lord foxham face concealed with a dark hood , and [his]157-lord foxham bright armour covered by a long russet mantle of a poor appearance .

" [Young Shelton]174-young shelton , "[76-dick] [he]76-dick said , " are [ye]174-young shelton for [sea]3475-sea , then , truly ? "[76-dick]

" [[My]74-master shelton lord]3102-my lord , "[74-master shelton] replied [Richard]74-master shelton , " [they]1625-a dozen of the outlaws lie about [the house]321-the house with [horsemen]1526-horsemen ; it may not be reached from [the land side]4097-the land side without alarum ; and [Sir Daniel]72-sir daniel once advertised of [our]4098-we adventure , [we]4098-we can no more carry it to a good end than , saving [your]174-young shelton presence , [we]4098-we could ride upon the wind . Now , in going round by [sea]3475-sea , [we]4098-we do run some peril by the elements ; but , what much outweighteth all , [we]4098-we have a chance to make good [our]4098-we purpose and bear off [the maid]4055-the maid . "[74-master shelton]

" Well , "[157-lord foxham] returned [Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham , " lead on . [I]157-lord foxham will , in some sort , follow [you]76-dick for shame s sake ; but [I]157-lord foxham own [I]157-lord foxham would [I]157-lord foxham were in bed . "[157-lord foxham]

" Here , then , "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick . " Hither [we]4098-we go to fetch [[our]4098-we pilot]4101-our pilot . "[76-dick]

And [he]76-dick led the way to [the rude alehouse]1628-the rude alehouse where [he]76-dick had given rendezvous to [a portion of [[his]76-dick men]417-his men]1629-a portion of his men . Some of these [he]76-dick found lingering round the door outside ; [others]237-others had pushed more boldly in , and , choosing places as near as possible to where [they]417-his men saw [[their]417-his men comrade]1632-their comrade , gathered close about [Lawless]132-lawless and [the two shipmen]1633-the two shipmen . [These]1634-these , to judge by the distempered countenance and cloudy eye , had long since gone beyond the boundaries of moderation ; and as [Richard]74-master shelton entered , closely followed by [Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham , [they]1635-they were [all three tuning up an old , pitiful sea - ditty , to the chorus of the wailing of the gale]1636-all three tuning up an old , pitiful sea - ditty , to the chorus of the wailing of the gale .

[The young leader]1637-the young leader cast a rapid glance about [the shed]1638-the shed . The fire had just been replenished , and gave forth volumes of black smoke , so that it was difficult to see clearly in the further corners . It was plain , however , that [the outlaws]3479-the outlaws very largely outnumbered [the remainder of [the guests]1641-the guests]1640-the remainder of the guests . Satisfied upon this point , in case of any failure in the operation of [his]76-dick plan , [Dick]76-dick strode up to the table and resumed [his]76-dick place upon the bench .

" Hey ? "[1580-the skipper] cried [the skipper]1580-the skipper , tipsily , " who are [ye]1637-the young leader , hey ? "[1580-the skipper]

" [I]76-dick want a word with [you]1643-the shipman without , [Master Arblaster]175-master arblaster , "[76-dick] returned [Dick]76-dick ; " and here is what [we]1644-we shall talk of . "[76-dick] And [he]76-dick showed [him]1637-the young leader a gold noble in the glimmer of the firelight .

[The shipman]1643-the shipman s eyes burned , although [he]1643-the shipman still failed to recognise [[our]1644-we hero]1645-our hero .

" Ay , [boy]3344-boy , "[76-dick] [he]76-dick said , " [I]76-dick am with [you]3344-boy . [Gossip]173-arblaster , [I]76-dick will be back anon . Drink fair , [gossip]4064-gossip ; "[76-dick] and , taking [Dick]76-dick s arm to steady [his]76-dick uneven steps , [he]76-dick walked to the door of [the alehouse]1646-the alehouse .

As soon as [he]76-dick was over the threshold , ten strong arms had seized and bound [him]76-dick ; and in two minutes more , with [his]76-dick limbs trussed one to another , and a good gag in [his]76-dick mouth , [he]76-dick had been tumbled neck and crop into [a neighbouring hay - barn]1647-a neighbouring hay - barn . Presently , [[his]76-dick man]1648-his man [Tom]102-tom , similarly secured , was tossed beside [him]76-dick , and [the pair]805-the pair were left to [their]805-the pair uncouth reflections for the night .

And now , as the time for concealment had gone by , [[Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham s followers]1650-lord foxham s followers were summoned by a preconcerted signal , and [the party]282-the party , boldly taking possession of [as many boats]1652-as many boats as [their]282-the party numbers required , pulled in a flotilla for the light in [the rigging of [the ship]4061-the ship]1653-the rigging of the ship . Long before [the last man]1655-the last man had climbed to [the deck of [the Good Hope]172-the good hope]1656-the deck of the good hope , the sound of furious shouting from [the shore]1309-the shore showed that [a part , at least , of [the seamen]1659-the seamen]1658-a part , at least , of the seamen had discovered the loss of [their]1659-the seamen skiffs .

But it was now too late , whether for recovery or revenge . Out of [some forty fighting men]1660-some forty fighting men now mustered in [the stolen ship]1661-the stolen ship , eight had been to [sea]3475-sea , and could play the part of [mariners]1663-mariners . With the aid of these , a slice of sail was got upon [her]172-the good hope . The cable was cut . [Lawless]132-lawless , vacillating on [his]132-lawless feet , and still shouting the chorus of sea - ballads , took the long tiller in [his]132-lawless hands : and [the Good Hope]4065-the good hope began to flit forward into the darkness of the night , and to face the great waves beyond [the harbour bar]1665-the harbour bar .

[Richard]74-master shelton took [his]74-master shelton place beside the weather rigging . Except for [the ship]4061-the ship s own lantern , and for some lights in [Shoreby town]1667-shoreby town , that were already fading to leeward , [the whole world of air]1668-the whole world of air was as black as in a pit . Only from time to time , as [the Good Hope]172-the good hope swooped dizzily down into [the valley of the rollers]1669-the valley of the rollers , a crest would break a great cataract of snowy foam would leap in one instant into being and , in an instant more , would stream into the wake and vanish .

[Many of [the men]405-the men]1670-many of the men lay holding on and praying aloud ; [many more]1672-many more were sick , and had crept into the bottom , where [they]1672-many more sprawled among the cargo . And what with the extreme violence of the motion , and the continued drunken bravado of [Lawless]132-lawless , still shouting and singing at the helm , the stoutest heart on board may have nourished a shrewd misgiving as to the result .

But [Lawless]132-lawless , as if guided by an instinct , steered [the ship]4061-the ship across [the breakers]1674-the breakers , struck the lee of [a great sandbank]1675-a great sandbank , where [they]1676-they sailed for awhile in smooth water , and presently after laid [her]4065-the good hope alongside [a rude , stone pier]1677-a rude , stone pier , where [she]4065-the good hope was hastily made fast , and lay ducking and grinding in the dark .

CHAPTER V [THE GOOD HOPE]4065-the good hope continued

[The pier]1679-the pier was not far distant from [the house in which [Joanna]117-joanna lay]1680-the house in which joanna lay ; it now only remained to get [the men on shore]1681-the men on shore , to surround [the house]321-the house with [a strong party]1683-a strong party , burst in the door and carry off [the captive]1684-the captive . [They]1681-the men on shore might then regard [themselves]1681-the men on shore as done with the Good Hope ; it had placed [them]1681-the men on shore on the rear of [[their]1681-the men on shore enemies]409-their enemies ; and the retreat , whether [they]1681-the men on shore should succeed or fail in the main enterprise , would be directed with a greater measure of hope in the direction of [the forest]246-the forest and [my]0-i [Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham s reserve .

To get [the men on shore]1681-the men on shore , however , was no easy task ; [many]1688-many had been sick , all were pierced with cold ; the promiscuity and disorder on board had shaken [their]1681-the men on shore discipline ; the movement of [the ship]4061-the ship and the darkness of the night had cowed [their]1681-the men on shore spirits . [They]1681-the men on shore made a rush upon [the pier]1679-the pier ; [[my]0-i lord]3102-my lord , with [his]3102-my lord sword drawn on [[his]3102-my lord own retainers]1692-his own retainers , must throw [himself]3102-my lord in front ; and this impulse of rabblement was not restrained without a certain clamour of voices , highly to be regretted in the case .

When some degree of order had been restored , [Dick]76-dick , with [a few chosen men]1693-a few chosen men , set forth in advance . The darkness on [shore]585-shore , by contrast with the flashing of the surf , appeared before [him]76-dick like a solid body ; and the howling and whistling of the gale drowned any lesser noise .

[He]76-dick had scarce reached the end of [the pier]1679-the pier , however , when there fell a lull of the wind ; and in this [he]76-dick seemed to hear on [shore]585-shore the hollow footing of horses and the clash of arms . Checking [[his]76-dick immediate followers]1697-his immediate followers , [he]76-dick passed forward a step or two alone , even setting foot upon the down ; and here [he]76-dick made sure [he]76-dick could detect the shape of [men]3205-men and horses moving . A strong discouragement assailed [him]76-dick . If [[their]3205-men enemies]409-their enemies were really on the watch , if [they]409-their enemies had beleaguered [the shoreward end of the pier]1700-the shoreward end of the pier , [he]76-dick and [Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham were taken in a posture of very poor defence , [the sea]1479-the sea behind , [the men]405-the men jostled in the dark upon [a narrow causeway]1703-a narrow causeway . [He]76-dick gave a cautious whistle , the signal previously agreed upon .

It proved to be a signal far more than [he]76-dick desired . Instantly there fell , through the black night , a shower of arrows sent at a venture ; and so close were [the men]405-the men huddled on [the pier]1679-the pier that [more than one was hit]1706-more than one was hit , and the arrows were answered with cries of both fear and pain . In this first discharge , [Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham was struck down ; [Hawksley]170-hawksley had [him]76-dick carried on board again at once ; and [[his]170-hawksley men]417-his men , during the brief remainder of the skirmish , fought when [they]417-his men fought at all without guidance . That was perhaps the chief cause of the disaster which made haste to follow .

At the shore end of [the pier]1679-the pier , for perhaps a minute , [Dick]76-dick held [his]76-dick own with a handful ; [one or two were wounded upon either side]1709-one or two were wounded upon either side ; steel crossed steel ; nor had there been the least signal of advantage , when in the twinkling of an eye the tide turned against the party from [the ship]4061-the ship . [Someone]1711-someone cried out that all was lost ; [the men]405-the men were in the very humour to lend an ear to a discomfortable counsel ; the cry was taken up . " On board , [lads]3497-lads , for [your]3497-lads lives ! "[992-another] cried [another]992-another . A third , with the true instinct of [the coward]1714-the coward , raised that inevitable report on all retreats : " [We]405-the men are betrayed ! "[992-another] And in a moment [the whole mass of men]1715-the whole mass of men went surging and jostling backward down [the pier]1679-the pier , turning [their]1715-the whole mass of men defenceless backs on [[their]1715-the whole mass of men pursuers]1717-their pursuers and piercing the night with craven outcry .

[One coward]1718-one coward thrust off [the ship]4061-the ship s stern , while [another]992-another still held [her]1718-one coward by the bows . [The fugitives]1721-the fugitives leaped , screaming , and were hauled on board , or fell back and perished in [the sea]1479-the sea . [Some]3511-some were cut down upon [the pier]1679-the pier by [the pursuers]387-the pursuers . [Many]1688-many were injured on [the ship]4061-the ship s deck in the blind haste and terror of the moment , [one man]990-one man leaping upon another , and [a third on both]1729-a third on both . At last , and whether by design or accident , the bows of [the Good Hope]172-the good hope were liberated ; and [the ever - ready Lawless , who had maintained [his]1730-the ever - ready lawless , who had maintained his place at the helm through all the hurly - burly by sheer strength of body and a liberal use of the cold steel place at the helm through all the hurly - burly by sheer strength of body and a liberal use of the cold steel]1730-the ever - ready lawless , who had maintained his place at the helm through all the hurly - burly by sheer strength of body and a liberal use of the cold steel , instantly clapped [her]1718-one coward on the proper tack . [The ship]4061-the ship began to move once more forward on [the stormy sea]1732-the stormy sea , its scuppers running blood , [its]4061-the ship deck heaped with [fallen men]1733-fallen men , sprawling and struggling in the dark .

Thereupon , [Lawless]132-lawless sheathed [his]132-lawless dagger , and turning to [[his]132-lawless next neighbour]1734-his next neighbour , " [I]132-lawless have left [my]132-lawless mark on [them]1735-them , [gossip]4064-gossip , "[132-lawless] said [he]132-lawless , " the yelping , [coward hounds]4106-coward hounds . "[132-lawless]

Now , while [they]1735-them were all leaping and struggling for [their]1735-them lives , [the men]405-the men had not appeared to observe the rough shoves and cutting stabs with which [Lawless]132-lawless had held [his]132-lawless post in the confusion . But perhaps [they]405-the men had already begun to understand somewhat more clearly , or perhaps another ear had overheard , [the helmsman]1737-the helmsman s speech .

[Panic - stricken troops]1738-panic - stricken troops recover slowly , and [men who have just disgraced [themselves]1739-men who have just disgraced themselves by cowardice , as if to wipe out the memory of their fault by cowardice , as if to wipe out the memory of [their]1739-men who have just disgraced themselves by cowardice , as if to wipe out the memory of their fault fault]1739-men who have just disgraced themselves by cowardice , as if to wipe out the memory of their fault , will sometimes run straight into the opposite extreme of insubordination . So it was now ; and [the same men who had thrown away [their]1740-the same men who had thrown away their weapons and been hauled , feet foremost , into the good hope weapons and been hauled , feet foremost , into [the Good Hope]172-the good hope]1740-the same men who had thrown away their weapons and been hauled , feet foremost , into the good hope , began to cry out upon [[their]1740-the same men who had thrown away their weapons and been hauled , feet foremost , into the good hope leaders]1741-their leaders , and demand that [someone]1711-someone should be punished .

This growing ill - feeling turned upon [Lawless]132-lawless .

In order to get a proper offing , [the old outlaw]1743-the old outlaw had put the head of [the Good Hope]172-the good hope to seaward .

" What ! "[1744-one of the grumblers] bawled [one of [the grumblers]1745-the grumblers]1744-one of the grumblers , " [he]132-lawless carrieth [us]1745-the grumblers to [seaward]4107-seaward ! "[1744-one of the grumblers]

" Tis sooth , "[992-another] cried [another]992-another . " Nay , [we]1745-the grumblers are betrayed for sure . "[992-another]

And [they]1745-the grumblers all began to cry out in chorus that [they]1745-the grumblers were betrayed , and in shrill tones and with abominable oaths bade [Lawless]132-lawless go about - ship and bring [them]1745-the grumblers speedily [ashore]602-ashore . [Lawless]132-lawless , grinding [his]132-lawless teeth , continued in silence to steer the true course , guiding [the Good Hope]172-the good hope among the formidable billows . To [their]1745-the grumblers empty terrors , as to [their]1745-the grumblers dishonourable threats , between drink and dignity [he]132-lawless scorned to make reply . [The malcontents]1748-the malcontents drew together a little abaft the mast , and it was plain [they]1748-the malcontents were like barnyard cocks , " crowing for courage . "[1748-the malcontents] Presently [they]1748-the malcontents would be fit for any extremity of injustice or ingratitude . [Dick]76-dick began to mount by the ladder , eager to interpose ; but one of [the outlaws]3479-the outlaws , who was also something of [a seaman]1750-a seaman , got beforehand .

" [Lads]3497-lads , "[1751-he] [he]1751-he began , " [y]3497-lads are right wooden heads , [I]1751-he think . For to get back , by the mass , [we]3497-lads must have an offing , must [we]3497-lads not ? And [this old Lawless]4109-this old lawless "[1751-he]

Someone struck [the speaker]691-the speaker on the mouth , and the next moment , as a fire springs among dry straw , [he]132-lawless was felled upon [the deck]1753-the deck , trampled under the feet , and despatched by the daggers of [[his]132-lawless cowardly companions]1754-his cowardly companions . At this the wrath of [Lawless]132-lawless rose and broke .

" [Steer]4110-steer [yourselves]4110-steer , "[132-lawless] [he]132-lawless bellowed , with a curse ; and , careless of the result , [he]132-lawless left the helm .

[The Good Hope]172-the good hope was , at that moment , trembling on the summit of a swell . [She]172-the good hope subsided , with sickening velocity , upon the farther side . A wave , like a great black bulwark , hove immediately in front of [her]172-the good hope ; and , with a staggering blow , [she]172-the good hope plunged headforemost through [that liquid hill]1755-that liquid hill . The green water passed right over [her]172-the good hope from stem to stern , as high as [a man]3107-a man s knees ; the sprays ran higher than the mast ; and [she]172-the good hope rose again upon the other side , with an appalling , tremulous indecision , like a beast that has been deadly wounded .

[Six or seven of [the malcontents]1748-the malcontents]1757-six or seven of the malcontents had been carried bodily overboard ; and as for the remainder , when [they]1757-six or seven of the malcontents found [their]1757-six or seven of the malcontents tongues again , it was to bellow to [the saints]3104-the saints and wail upon [Lawless]132-lawless to come back and take the tiller .

Nor did [Lawless]132-lawless wait to be twice bidden . The terrible result of [his]132-lawless fling of just resentment sobered [him]132-lawless completely . [He]132-lawless knew , better than [any one on board]1760-any one on board , how nearly [the Good Hope]172-the good hope had gone bodily down below [their]1761-we feet ; and [he]132-lawless could tell , by the laziness with which [she]172-the good hope met [the sea]1479-the sea , that the peril was by no means over .

[Dick , who had been thrown down by the concussion and half drowned]1763-dick , who had been thrown down by the concussion and half drowned , rose wading to [his]1763-dick , who had been thrown down by the concussion and half drowned knees in [the swamped well of the stern]1764-the swamped well of the stern , and crept to [the old helmsman]1765-the old helmsman s side .

" [Lawless]132-lawless , "[1763-dick , who had been thrown down by the concussion and half drowned] [he]1763-dick , who had been thrown down by the concussion and half drowned said , " [we]1761-we do all depend on [you]132-lawless ; [y]132-lawless are [a brave , steady man]4111-a brave , steady man , indeed , and crafty in the management of [ships]4112-ships ; [I]1763-dick , who had been thrown down by the concussion and half drowned shall put [three sure men]4113-three sure men to watch upon [your]132-lawless safety . "[1763-dick , who had been thrown down by the concussion and half drowned]

" [Bootless]176-bootless , [[my]1766-the steersman master]3094-my master , bootless , "[1766-the steersman] said [the steersman]1766-the steersman , peering forward through the dark . " [We]1761-we come every moment somewhat clearer of [these sandbanks]4115-these sandbanks ; with every moment , then , the sea packeth upon [us]1761-we heavier , and for [all these whimperers]4116-all these whimperers , [they]4116-all these whimperers will presently be on [their]4116-all these whimperers backs . For , [[my]1766-the steersman master]3094-my master , tis a right mystery , but true , there never yet was [a bad man that was [a good shipman]4119-a good shipman]4118-a bad man that was a good shipman . [None but the honest and the bold]4120-none but the honest and the bold can endure [me]1766-the steersman this tossing of [a ship]4059-a ship . "[1766-the steersman]

" Nay , [Lawless]132-lawless , "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick , laughing , " that is [a right shipman]4122-a right shipman s byword , and hath no more of sense than the whistle of the wind . But , prithee , how go [we]1761-we ? Do [we]1761-we lie well ? Are [we]1761-we in good case ? "[76-dick]

" [Master Shelton]74-master shelton , "[132-lawless] replied [Lawless]132-lawless , " [I]132-lawless have been [a Grey Friar]3489-a grey friar [I]132-lawless praise fortune [an archer]4124-an archer , [a thief]4125-a thief , and [a shipman]3491-a shipman . Of all these coats , [I]132-lawless had the best fancy to die in [the Grey Friar s]4127-the grey friar s , as [ye]4128-ye may readily conceive , and the least fancy to die in [John Shipman]177-john shipman s tarry jacket ; and that for two excellent good reasons : first , that the death might take [a man]3107-a man suddenly ; and second , for the horror of that great , salt smother and [welter]4130-welter under [my]132-lawless foot here "[132-lawless] and [Lawless]132-lawless stamped with [his]132-lawless foot . " Howbeit , "[132-lawless] [he]132-lawless went on , " an [I]132-lawless die not [a sailor]4131-a sailor s death , and that this night , [I]132-lawless shall owe a tall candle to [[our]4132-our Lady]4133-our lady . "[132-lawless]

" Is it so ? "[76-dick] asked [Dick]76-dick .

" It is right so , "[1231-the outlaw] replied [the outlaw]1231-the outlaw . " Do [ye]4128-ye not feel how heavy and dull [she]4133-our lady moves upon the waves ? Do [ye]4128-ye not hear the water washing in [her]4133-our lady hold ? [She]4133-our lady will scarce mind the rudder even now . Bide till [she]4133-our lady has settled a bit lower ; and [she]4133-our lady will either go down below [your]4128-ye boots like a stone image , or drive ashore here , under [our]4132-our lee , and come all to pieces like a twist of string . "[1231-the outlaw]

" [Ye]76-dick speak with a good courage , "[76-dick] returned [Dick]76-dick . " [Ye]76-dick are not then appalled ? "[76-dick]

" Why , [master]3237-master , "[132-lawless] answered [Lawless]132-lawless , " if ever [a man]3107-a man had [an ill crew]4136-an ill crew to come to [port]4137-port with , it is [I]132-lawless [a renegade friar]4138-a renegade friar , [a thief]4125-a thief , and [all the rest on t. Well]4140-all the rest on t. well , [ye]4128-ye may wonder , but [I]132-lawless keep a good hope in [my]132-lawless wallet ; and if that [I]132-lawless be to drown , [I]132-lawless will drown with a bright eye , [Master Shelton]74-master shelton , and a steady hand . "[132-lawless]

[Dick]76-dick returned no answer ; but [he]76-dick was surprised to find [the old vagabond of so resolute a temper]1768-the old vagabond of so resolute a temper , and fearing some fresh violence or treachery , set forth upon [his]76-dick quest for [three sure men]4113-three sure men . [The great bulk of [the men]405-the men]1770-the great bulk of the men had now deserted [the deck]1753-the deck , which was continually wetted with the flying sprays , and where [they]1770-the great bulk of the men lay exposed to the shrewdness of the winter wind . [They]1770-the great bulk of the men had gathered , instead , into the hold of [the merchandise]1773-the merchandise , among the butts of wine , and lighted by two swinging lanterns .

Here a few kept up the form of revelry , and toasted [each other]664-each other deep in [Arblaster]173-arblaster s Gascony wine . But as [the Good Hope]172-the good hope continued to tear through the smoking waves , and toss [her]172-the good hope stem and stern alternately high in air and deep into white foam , the number of [these jolly companions]1775-these jolly companions diminished with every moment and with every lurch . [Many]1688-many sat apart , tending [their]1688-many hurts , but [the majority]1777-the majority were already prostrated with sickness , and lay moaning in the bilge .

[Greensheve]160-greensheve , [Cuckow]136-tom , and [a young fellow of [Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham s whom [Dick]76-dick had already remarked for [his]76-dick intelligence and spirit]1778-a young fellow of lord foxham s whom dick had already remarked for his intelligence and spirit , were still , however , [both fit to understand and willing to obey]1779-both fit to understand and willing to obey . [These Dick]76-dick set , as [a body - guard]1780-a body - guard , about [the person of [the steersman]1766-the steersman]1781-the person of the steersman , and then , with a last look at the black sky and sea , [he]76-dick turned and went below into [the cabin]1608-the cabin , whither [Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham had been carried by [[his]157-lord foxham servants]1784-his servants .

[CHAPTER VI THE GOOD HOPE]178-chapter vi the good hope concluded

The moans of [the wounded baron]1785-the wounded baron blended with the wailing of [the ship]4061-the ship s dog . The poor animal , whether [he]1785-the wounded baron was merely sick at heart to be separated from [[his]1785-the wounded baron friends]1787-his friends , or whether [he]1785-the wounded baron indeed recognised some peril in the labouring of [the ship]4061-the ship , raised [his]1785-the wounded baron cries , like minute - guns , above the roar of wave and weather ; and [the more superstitious of [the men]405-the men]1789-the more superstitious of the men heard , in these sounds , the knell of the Good Hope .

[Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham had been laid in a berth upon a fur cloak . A little lamp burned dim before [the Virgin in the bulkhead]1791-the virgin in the bulkhead , and by its glimmer [Dick]76-dick could see the pale countenance and hollow eyes of [the hurt man]1003-the hurt man .

" [I]76-dick am sore hurt , "[76-dick] said [he]76-dick . " Come near to [my]76-dick side , [young Shelton]74-master shelton ; let there be one by [me]76-dick who , at least , is [gentle born]4141-gentle born ; for after having lived nobly and richly all the days of [my]76-dick life , this is a sad pass that [I]76-dick should get [my]76-dick hurt in a little ferreting skirmish , and die here , in [a foul , cold ship upon [the sea]1479-the sea]4142-a foul , cold ship upon the sea , among [broken men and churls]4144-broken men and churls . "[76-dick]

" Nay , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , "[76-dick] said [Dick]76-dick , " [I]76-dick pray rather to [the saints]3104-the saints that [ye]3102-my lord will recover [you]3102-my lord of [your]3102-my lord hurt , and come soon and sound ashore . "[76-dick]

" How ! "[1511-his lordship] demanded [[his]76-dick lordship]1511-his lordship . " Come sound ashore ? There is , then , a question of it ? "[1511-his lordship]

" [The ship]4061-the ship laboureth [the sea]1479-the sea is grievous and contrary , "[309-the lad] replied [the lad]309-the lad ; " and by what [I]309-the lad can learn of [[my]309-the lad fellow]4149-my fellow that steereth [us]4150-we , [we]4150-we shall do well , indeed , if [we]4150-we come dryshod to [land]3959-land . "[309-the lad]

" Ha ! "[1354-the baron] said [the baron]1354-the baron , gloomily , " thus shall every terror attend upon the passage of [my]1354-the baron soul ! [Sir]3184-sir , pray rather to live hard , that [ye]3184-sir may die easy , than to be fooled and fluted all through life , as to the pipe and tabor , and , in the last hour , be plunged among misfortunes ! Howbeit , [I]1354-the baron have that upon [my]1354-the baron mind that must not be delayed . [We]4150-we have [no priest aboard]4153-no priest aboard ? "[1354-the baron]

" None , "[76-dick] replied [Dick]76-dick .

" [Here]742-here , then , to [my]157-lord foxham secular interests , "[157-lord foxham] resumed [Lord Foxham]157-lord foxham : " [ye]3184-sir must be as good a friend to [me]157-lord foxham dead , as [I]157-lord foxham found [you]3184-sir [a gallant enemy]4155-a gallant enemy when [I]157-lord foxham was living . [I]157-lord foxham fall in an evil hour for [me]157-lord foxham , for [England]22-england , and for [them]4156-them that trusted [me]157-lord foxham . [[My]157-lord foxham men]3751-my men are being brought by [Hamley]158-hamley [he]158-hamley that was [[your]3184-sir rival]4158-your rival ; [they]3751-my men will rendezvous in [the long holm at [Holywood]14-holywood]4159-the long holm at holywood ; this ring from off [my]157-lord foxham finger will accredit [you]3184-sir to represent [mine]157-lord foxham orders ; and [I]157-lord foxham shall write , besides , two words upon this paper , bidding [Hamley]158-hamley yield to [you]3184-sir [the damsel]4160-the damsel . Will [he]158-hamley obey ? [I]157-lord foxham know not . "[157-lord foxham]

" But , [[my]76-dick lord]3102-my lord , what orders ? "[76-dick] inquired [Dick]76-dick .

" Ay , "[1354-the baron] quoth [the baron]1354-the baron , " ay the orders ; "[1354-the baron] and [he]1354-the baron looked upon [Dick]76-dick with hesitation . " Are [ye]76-dick [Lancaster]7-lancaster or [York]8-york ? "[1354-the baron] [he]1354-the baron asked , at length .

" [I]76-dick shame to say it , "[76-dick] answered [Dick]76-dick , " [I]76-dick can scarce clearly answer . But so much [I]76-dick think is certain : since [I]76-dick serve with [Ellis Duckworth]100-ellis , [I]76-dick serve [the house of [York]8-york]4162-the house of york . Well , if that be so , [I]76-dick declare for [York]8-york . "[76-dick]

" It is well , "[311-the other] returned [the other]311-the other ; " it is exceeding well . For , truly , had [ye]76-dick said [Lancaster]7-lancaster , [I]311-the other wot not for [the world]235-the world what [I]311-the other had done . But sith [ye]76-dick are for [York]8-york , follow [me]311-the other . [I]311-the other came hither but to watch [these lords]4164-these lords at [Shoreby]20-shoreby , while [[mine]311-the other excellent young lord]4165-mine excellent young lord , [[Richard]74-master shelton of [Gloucester]207-dick]4166-richard of gloucester , 1 prepareth a sufficient force to fall upon and scatter [them]4164-these lords . [I]311-the other have made [me]311-the other notes of [their]4164-these lords strength , what watch [they]4164-these lords keep , and how [they]4164-these lords lie ; and these [I]311-the other was to deliver to [[my]311-the other young lord]4167-my young lord on Sunday , an hour before noon , at [St. Bride s Cross]41-st. bride s cross beside [the forest]246-the forest .
